headline: Dont believe the hype this will end your career
pros:
-Good PTO
-Great maternity leave
-Nice to have extra holiday time
cons:
-Absolutely no career advancement. When I was hired on I was told there are tons of growth options because I have a degree. I raised my hand and leaned in to every opportunity that came my way but was passed over 8 times in one year. After talking to other admin it can take 8 to 10 years to find a lateral role in another department. I was later told by a manager that Deloitte simple doesnt have a lot of advancement options. 
-There is a strict anti-bullying policy but if your a partner or well liked you can bully whomever you please. I had a nasty partner for two years, I had taken him on after his former admin had a breakdown. When we finally parted ways it was because he had ask for a new admin not because I had complained for two years about being bullied. 
-Dont bother complaining to your manager about anything. They are more interested in covering their butt then having your back. 
-Dont bother reporting to the hotline. While there is an anti-retaliation policy it apparently is not enforced. 
-You are told you can "grow" your career this appears to mean you will take on more work for the same title and same pay. 
-The environment is like being in high school instead of being part of a team. There was an admin that would walk behind my cube and peak over to see what I was doing and this is completely acceptable. 
-How well your liked determines what you can get away with. If I was 10 minutes late my manager would ping me but there were admin that would go to the gym at 10am or arrive anywhere between 9 and 11 then leave between 3 and 4. 
-There are no yearly reviews or bonuses. You are told you are a number and replaceable. Since you cost more then your bring in there is no effort to grow you. 
-Admin come in at a level 3 with no option to advance but level 4 and above have the option to have mentors, take advancement classes and be part of special projects. 
-They preach a lot of diversity and inclusion. There is an inclusion council but you have to be recommended by a current member then voted in. 85% of partners are white males. There used to be inclusion groups for cultures but it was too much of a hassle and they were dissolved.
-Your time is not respected. You are expected to be available at all hours of the day and night. If you point out that you entitled to off time as well your job description will be printed for you so you can review what your responsibilities are. 
-Managers are promoted at random and then not provided any training on how to manage others or how to lead so people will follow.

headline: Overall Fine

cons: Vast majority of the work is large tech implementations and not that interesting. You'll probably end up working with some absolutely horrible people with no boundaries or desire to help you grow. Hours can be long. While good exposure, day-to-day can be very mundane (think reformatting decks, meeting notes, setting up calls) as the majority of what you do.

headline: Incredibly Toxic Culture
pros: Deloitte is a powerful brand and gives you good experience. Two years or more here WILL open doors for you elsewhere. Deloitte also does a great job of showing you what a deliverable should look like. The company is big and there’s generally a lot of opportunity to try new things.
cons:
1. The culture at Deloitte is utterly toxic. There is no division for work-life balance and employees frequently behave like high schoolers to each other. In my two years at Deloitte across several major accounts there was constant drama within my vicinity that I had to deal with / avoid on a daily basis. Working through office politics was often harder than the job itself.
2. Federal contracting is broken. This isn’t necessarily D’s fault but most projects objectively fail or otherwise do not contribute any meaningful value to federal clients. It often ends up feeling like stealing with extra steps.
3. The sausage making is obscene. I observed multiple fresh-out-of-state-college kids be billed as highly specialized subject matter experts to their client which was at least very wrong and at most...much worse. Deliverables often get slapped together last minute and clients routinely called us out for making things up as we went.

headline: The best of the best big four
pros: Great benefits and PTO is generous. They provide a well being subsidy of $500 per year to be used for work out classes and equipment. Even massages! Very well structured organization with lots of opportunity to learn and grow. Process-oriented and forward thinking. I felt proud to work here and feel that I worked among the best of the best. Also, I worked fully remote for the duration of my role which enabled a very comfortable work day. My job was very demanding but fulfilling and exciting. I did not mind the busyness since I was working from home daily.
cons: Very demanding, long hours at times. Otherwise, enjoyed the role and firm very much!

Overall a BIG NO to DELOITTE if you are joining at Senior Consultant or Above level.

1. There is no life when they say 'Work-Life Balance'.
2. If something goes wrong for the second time, choose your way out to the company. Talking to leadership again and again could ruin your repo.
3. You might be having a lot of leaves but probably would not be able to take them ever because all the projects are always in red or orange and taking leaves doesn't get taken in a positive note. Especially if you do not live in the same city you are working and would need long leaves to say of 20 days.

headline: Welcome to the Meat Grinder
pros: Great airline and hotel points. You'll gain fifteen pounds eating junk food. Once in a while you'll get to go to Deloitte University in Dallas.
cons: If you're hired as a Specialist, your role in "the firm" will never be clearly defined. Though you're hired in a technical specialty, your performance will be assessed against Management Track expectations. Often, Specialist Masters are hired makjng $165,000 per year, much more than their counterpart managers. If you are, expect your reviews to be sandbagged and to be run out of "the firm" as a cost savings. You'll never be fully utilized and you'll struggle to find project work relevant to your skills set. You'll routinely work until 2:00 and 3:00 AM trying to please people who cannot be satisfied, i.e., Senior Managers and Partners.

headline: Non existent processes and transparency leads to discrimination
pros:
- Good money (for me)
- Good commute (for me)
- Decent professional courtesy
cons:
- The developers at Deloitte have around 2/3 yrs experience as developers, yet are given roles such as "lead developer" and "lead achitect" - this is never questioned or shown any concern about. What you end up with is poorly designed systems that cannot support any sort of edge cases, or scale of users. I've heard Deloitte have also started selling these same products to the Government at millions of pounds of cost to the taxpayer - this concerns me greatly.

- As projects are run in vacuums, managers of projects completely dictate the culture and narrative in the project. This means that if the manager on your project is classist, racist, sexist, homophobic, incompetent, plays favourites, dismisses concerns, lies to partners and/or clients (all experiences I've seen or heard of), then this is just going to be your experience working at Deloitte and there is nothing you can do about it. Deloitte themselves do not check up on the professionalism, competence, or culture of a project, and there is no expectation no the project to be transparent. If you're not a straight, white, middle class male, then this will affect you at some point.

- Silly corporate games by immature people in their twenties thinking they're still in high school and they're reliving "mean girls". Not a major issue but can be an annoyance.

cons: They'll push only whom they like though you work-hard that doesn't mean you will get a good hike/bonus and promotion. The mindset of people(Manager and above) and cunningness is a way beyond that you can't think of. Too much politics and they give support only those who didn't oppose the management.

headline: S&O - Toxic culture
pros: Brand name in other markets, but within Hong Kong competes against other Big 4 and lower tier firms.
cons:
Firm will punish you (denying progression/promotion, low salary increment) if you are labelled as picking projects. All the emails about you owning your career, or how it's a safe space to speak up is just PR. Partners will passively punish you until you leave.

Toxic culture - most of the expats left S&O HK in a single wave, citing negative issues and outlook with current leadership and management
Verbal/emotional abuse - happens day to day if you work under a certain notorious partner in the insurance practice
Favoritism - certain individuals are propped up and allowed to pick projects of their choosing. The rest are tossed onto long engagements with no career growth. Speaking up by asking to roll off will only destroy your career.

Overall, S&O in HK operates more as a body shop than a strategy consulting firm

headline: Good place to work but not without a vice
pros:
Technically encourages to be at the best of your game
Focus on learning new technology, getting cross trained
Flexibility of working from home 
Flat hierarchy helps , everyone is reachable and listens to your concerns
Great policies to support safety , equality at workplace and prevention of any sort of harassment. Salary hikes are average and bonus is generally high. Parties are awesome :)
cons:
1. Work life balance is not good: Working on weekends, ,carrying your laptop to support work even when you're on leave or holiday is a normal expectation.
2. Firm Initiative: FI's are a scam that is there to ensure your performance in your project don't play the key role. It is free work you have to do apart from the client billable projects . Year end performance are linked to these FI's. Getting an FI in the first place is a task. After slogging in projects with client deliverables even if one manages to get an FI and work on it, year end you'll be told the FI was not impactful. 
3. Promotions depends mainly on your networking(read buttering) skills rather than efforts. 
4. Fairness of opportunity based on skills and efforts : All the manager's have a few favorite's and only those get fair opportunity of projects, FI's , recognition , apply for certification and a chance to apply for a visa if interested in going onshore.

headline: Politics, micromanagement and forget about skill
pros: I worked for Deloitte USI internal department called DAS( Deloitte Application Studios). DAS caters to all US application needs. The only pro for working in deloitte is the "brand tag" in your resume.
cons:
Where do I start. Lets take the following :
1) There's no place for skill. Even if you dont have skill to work you can still survive.
2)Your designation matters in every aspect. Be it decision making in any aspect( appraisal, judgment, biased feeling and even gossip) your position matters. The higher your level is the easier it to delegate/escape from responsibility and to do false claims.
3)Constant micromanagement. I repeat constant, you do get mails kind of ordering you to work from assigned desk so as to have a constant monitor on your progress. This will result in distrust towards leadership
4)WFH policies are a joke. You need to seek permission for WFH explaining a valid reason else it will be rejected.
5) Forget about Work life balance. You have to say yes to whatever the onsite team(US) asks.
6) An elaborated procedure to build your year's performance. Yet in the end you will get a good appraisal ,even after all the hard work, only if leadership feels like (totally biased).

In a summary, don't fall in love with your employer.

headline: Stimulating, lucrative, flexible, but demanding
pros: You have access to great clients, and almost peer colleagues I've worked with have been wonderful. For the upper echelons of the consulting/corporate world, Deloitte is very flexible and understanding about personal/family needs. 4 months paid paternity leave - pretty good for the US.
cons: Deloitte is a bureaucratic juggernaut with too much administrivia. Also, while it's a very flexible place to work, it's very demanding. Frequent nights and weekends are a given. You can find ways to reduce your workload and get close to 9-5 some weeks, but it's better to set your expectation that you'll work until 10, 11, 12, 1 with some regularity.

headline: A great place to train your soft skills and fill your CV
pros:
Lots of people to trade knowledge with.
Lots of areas of expertise to work on.
Low individual risk.
Focus on training and certifications.
cons:
A terrible place to evolve as a professional:
Long work hours( 10 hours daily for an average perfomance, lunch break is a joke; this is consistent and irrespective of the individual's performance).
People in the hierarchy usually have little to zero clue regarding the subject, they will hardly try to hear.(Knowledgeable individuals prefer to change companies for better compensation)
Efforts to manage lack of knowledge will have a negative impact on the individual that takes action.
These people will get credit of the work, even though their contribution could be negative.
The same people will take the blame away from themselves..
The individual is more dependent on the person above rather than its knowledge and effort.
More focus on the individual's profile rather than it's knowledge.
Flat and slow career path evolution; an indicator that productivity and knowledge is not appreciated.
Management communicates in a way that will bring the individual to a position unprofessional and unethical for discussion; apart from this management might try to make promises which cannot be fulfilled.
Management seems uncoordinated.
It is never clear who is the person in charge at company level, people will always avoid the responsibilities.
The firm's approach towards ethical and social matters feels as if it is only about the marketing.
Even though there are efforts for transparency with regards to evaluation and business matters, people are constantly working their way around to their benefits.

cons: The one thing i didn't like was the review process which was made from the top executives who we never met and its based off metrics on what you login instead from the art director who sees you work and sees you as a team player. At the end of the day its up to people on top level who decide if you deserve a raise or not, doesnt matter if they knew you as a person or worked with you. Since the team in Redbank was moved into the NYC office space that culture was hard to find.

headline: It's going down hill recklessly fast
pros:
1. Team mates. I have pleasant memories of working with genuinely smart & hard-working people.

2. Office space, meeting rooms, conference halls are all up class 

3. Deloitte hires the best facilities & services team & guards. They are the best in the business. Thank you for your service.

4. Impact Day/CSR programmes - 1 paid day dedicated to society, multiple avenues to pick and choose what cause one wants to support. Transparent reports on spending and status available for contributors. 

5. Diversity & Inclusion - Did not encounter or experience any gender discrimination.

6. Avenues to learn with curated learning, byte learning, Udemy, LinkedIn and other free subscription for employees.

7. HR(Talent) team responds faster than other employers in my experience.

8. Admin team, global relocation team are all prompt responders & best in the business.

9. Knowledge base portal has good reads & huge repository off articles and accelerators both technical and non-technical which are really helpful.

10. Learning and development team / SNET team - SNET team sets up sandbox environment to practice new tools, technologies and they are very responsive and technically skilled. Learning & development team shares regular calendar updates and plans multiple trainings based on firm pipelines and market trends.

11. Loop Survey - Anonymous 360 survey of leadership on various parameters can be submitted once a year. But if your lead is blessed by multiple "GODS" higher up he/she is immune to any feedback.

12. Gym, recreation centre - Gym is really up class but the TT room needs improvement as the ball sneaks through the holes resulting in waste of time fetching the ball.

13. On campus medical facilities and dark room - Available 24*7 and well kept. Please ask people to remove socks outside so that the bad odour is kept at bay.
cons:
To begin with Deloitte has quietly laid off scores of employees worldwide without blinking an eye during the peak of the worst global pandemic in the history of mankind. They gave a few hours to resign with 2 months’ pay or threatened to terminate without any pay-out. Many employers laid off during the pandemic but gave 3 or 6 or 9 some even 12 months’ pay. Some gave additional pay based on number of years served with the company. 6 years with company means 6 months additional pay + severance pay package.

A company's ethics are best evaluated in crisis. It was unethical on Deloitte's part to lay off without appropriate pay-outs.

For face saving they hired a handful and did propaganda everywhere to portray an image that they're hiring instead of firing as others.

Now the other "CONS"

1. The new appraisal & performance evaluation system is a sham & lacks transparency. Manager is GOD. 
There's no concrete grievance mechanism. Snapshot based on few questions might work for non-technical teams but certainly not for technical teams. The person answering those questions should be competent enough to understand the true meaning of those questions in the first place.

If your counsellor sleeps throughout the year & wakes up at the 11th hour you're doomed. Likely to be fired.

2. Hire & Fire policy. Deloitte is heavily invested in PR and branding, if they hire 10 folks, they will announce it all over but quietly layoff 1000 without a whisper.

3. Don't fall for the HR propaganda of Employee wellbeing, Mental health & "Our people are our asset". It's nothing but high decibel propaganda. When push comes to shove, they are best in the business with slaughtering "Human" resources inhumanely.

4. Gone are the days when Deloitte offered better pay packages. Venture out and you are likely to be paid much better.

5. Firm Initiatives - It's a good concept but blatantly misused and exploited. In Deloitte employees are expected to go and over beyond their project deliverables by doing firm initiatives for which more often than not employees are expected to network with higher ups. This is where the blatant exploitation occurs. Nepotism, Favouritism, Boot Lickism, add any "isms" you want to add. For someone who is not good at these qualities should definitely avoid Deloitte. In US firm initiative concept is not so much exploited but in India is hopeless. Ideas are stolen & given to favourite people at times.

6. "Glass Ceiling" - After a certain career level if you don't have the blessings of multiple "GODS" in the so-called leadership, it is impossible to survive & break the glass ceiling and go beyond a certain level. Manager & above specially.

7. Learning - The learnings are limited as most of Deloitte projects do not require hi fi tech skills. But they do provide avenues like Udemy and others to employees to upskill at their leisure.

8. The annual appraisal results are announced in May and hikes are rolled out in September thus delaying the whole cycle by 6 months. This is ridiculous which makes it tricky to plan your next potential jump & leaves a very small window considering employers demand last 3 months salary so 1 would want to show hiked up salary slips.

9. Work Culture - Its going downhill recklessly fast as the hiring at higher levels from other organizations have ruined the original "Deloitte" culture

10. Work life balance - It's difficult to maintain work life balance while working for Deloitte as apart from project work one has to slog for firm initiative hours which more often than not decides the rating, hike and bonus. Because people who screw on projects are fired anyways. So hardly anyone screws on their project.

11. Reward system - Rewards are exploited by managers blatantly and distributed many times to boot lickers or favourites. But this is not across the board. Many a deserving people also are awarded. But there is no checks and balances system. Also, one can work round the clock and put in all the efforts and still go unnoticed and unrewarded.

headline: It's going down hill recklessly fast
pros:
1. Team mates. I have pleasant memories of working with genuinely smart & hard-working people.

2. Office space, meeting rooms, conference halls are all up class 

3. Deloitte hires the best facilities & services team & guards. They are the best in the business. Thank you for your service.

4. Impact Day/CSR programmes - 1 paid day dedicated to society, multiple avenues to pick and choose what cause one wants to support. Transparent reports on spending and status available for contributors. 

5. Diversity & Inclusion - Did not encounter or experience any gender discrimination.

6. Avenues to learn with curated learning, byte learning, Udemy, LinkedIn and other free subscription for employees.

7. HR(Talent) team responds faster than other employers in my experience.

8. Admin team, global relocation team are all prompt responders & best in the business.

9. Knowledge base portal has good reads & huge repository off articles and accelerators both technical and non-technical which are really helpful.

10. Learning and development team / SNET team - SNET team sets up sandbox environment to practice new tools, technologies and they are very responsive and technically skilled. Learning & development team shares regular calendar updates and plans multiple trainings based on firm pipelines and market trends.

11. Loop Survey - Anonymous 360 survey of leadership on various parameters can be submitted once a year. But if your lead is blessed by multiple "GODS" higher up he/she is immune to any feedback.

12. Gym, recreation centre - Gym is really up class but the TT room needs improvement as the ball sneaks through the holes resulting in waste of time fetching the ball.

13. On campus medical facilities and dark room - Available 24*7 and well kept. Please ask people to remove socks outside so that the bad odour is kept at bay.
cons:

headline: YMMV - You should always know what you sign up for
pros:
• Exposure to several clients/industries
• Learning opportunities
cons:
• Pettiness all around, office politics. Your success depends on who you know (even if you suck at your job)
• Sometimes it feels you do all this work for nothing. Are you really providing value to your clients?
• Bunch of "work/life balance" talk, and no real delivery
• Bunch of "diversity and inclusion" talks, but in reality Deloitte is NOT proactive. My local office (which is located in a very diverse area) was mainly composed of white people. All of the diversity initiatives started only after the BLM protests.
• Senior management (think regional leaders and above) is so far removed from anything. And as mentioned previously in office politics, it all depends who you know at your local level.

headline: Great to build CV and experience
pros:
(Review of Consulting role)
- Lots of opportunities to work in different industries and types of project without having to change employer every time
- Motivated people
- People are driven to get stuff done
- If you want to follow a particular interest e.g set up a community or run a knowledge sharing session, usually fairly straightforward to get funding/support
- Staff are rewarded well e.g socials, bonus, benefits
- There's money for training
cons:
- A lot of projects expect long hours and big commitment - therefore, can be poor work/life balance
- Everything comes down to profit in the end
- Can be forced into roles that might not be the right for you if you end up in the wrong place at the wrong time
- Difficult to progress beyond Manager if you're more client delivery focused than sales/business growth focused

pros: good management work life balance

headline: I would say it's a nice place to be
pros:
I have found the culture in Deloitte to be rather good, with positive people around and nice to work with. Although, as a data scientist, working around technical people is quite fun.

I was expecting to be a bit more technically involved in data science projects, but I guess this strongly depends on the project, but more improtantly in which team you will land internally.
cons:
When you are facing the corporate part of Deloitte makes you really want to change. I also don't like the way the Senior leadership is behaving towards the more junior members (obviously not all, but I have noticed a bit of negativity).

Pay is bad, given the pandemic no pay rises, quite bad bonus for the junior members, mediocre benefits.

I didn't appreciate the latest round of promotions during the pandemic, quite lame excuses for the choices and a huge (relatively speaking) number of very senior people promoted, disproportionately compared to A/C/SC

headline: Don't waste your time
pros:
- A steady paycheck
- Good coworkers sailing with you on the same sinking ship
- If you are female and have the right physical qualities you can truly excel under the right male manager
cons:
- The upper management team (Ken/Marty) worked very hard to make life miserable for the slaves beneath their heels
- Due to COVID they stopped the 401k matching and bonuses and tried to cover with a story of losing money but in reality if you check the SEC listings you will notice they received larger bonuses and the company still did exceedingly well each quarter. They were able to force clients into taking on Work at home employees using COVID as the excuse. This gave them the leverage to lower and hire on new employees at lower rates using the excuse of the benefit of being able to work from ones own home to their advantage.

headline: Do not recommend Deloitte for experienced hires
pros: Good brand name on your resume. If you're a recent college graduate, I'm sure you'd learn a lot (although that could be said about most kids who enter the workforce with their first or second job).
cons:
Deloitte - like many consulting firms - use a "churn and burn" business model. Deloitte is successful because most employees do not stay for more than 3 years and are replaced with new hires who are cheaper and are willing to drink the Kool Aid. 

Deloitte is especially predatory with experienced hires. Their pitch, essentially, is: 1. You'll be hired to perform at your level of experience (false, Deloitte promotes from within and preference is given to those that have been there the longest/have the best connections); 2. You'll be promoted quickly (false, you'll constantly be disappointed by the structural bureaucracy that is designed to keep people as long as is tenable in the lowest paid position - their starting salary). 

The single most important negotiation you'll have at Deloitte is when you receive an offer letter with their lowball salary. If you're disappointed with your base salary or whatever you negotiate, you're essentially guaranteed to be disappointed during your entire tenure. Those who are promoted are only given the minimum within the pay-band for their level and aren't eligible for a bonus at the time of promotion. (There are other very real systems in place that keep your promoted salary below - trust me, unless you're 23 and never had a real job, you'll be infuriated by your new salary at promotion). 

Ask yourself how Deloitte can be profitable with massive overhead (their answer to low salary levels is that "we invest in you" with happy hours and trainings) and an ever evolving offerings in the marketplace (ie dubious client ROIs that are grossly overpriced)? The answer is that their business model (like most consulting firms and law firms) is to keep talent costs low and the PPMDs (Principals, Partners, and Managing Directors) skim their contracts, while providing little-to-no value add. 

I would recommend Deloitte or any of the Big 4 to recent college graduates as you'll learn a lot and can then leave for a better salary and more responsibilities. Experienced hires are the real suckers at a place like Deloitte and I would strongly discourage taking a position, unless you negotiate a competitive salary.

#There are two types of people who works at Deloitte, one got placements or made a switch from other company and Second type of people are the one who rules over first type of people, these old Deloitte people bullies you and make you feel that you do not exist and have no knowledge each and every day. The awards are all biased, to receive an award make sure you are good in flattering, if you can flatter your seniors you will survive and receive many awards.
#Deloitte they are worst when it comes to pay salary, 4-5% is maximum you can think of, This year they gave zero hike where as all other Companies provided good hike even there was Covid19.
#Coach concept - Deloitte provides you with a Coach (+1 level) who can give you all the jagrans but will never take a stand for you when it comes to appraisals and promotions
#Promotions they will keep giving to those who can flatter there leads 24x7, Hardworking people who talks straight and raise voice say good bye to your promotions, not a place for you folks to grow

headline: Be Careful What You Wish For
pros: Once you understand what you're doing and aren't being dragged in several different directions the work can be okay.
cons: You're expected to know more than is reasonable and high demands are made on you without regard to if it's deliverable or not. Communication is terrible, you are either bombarded with emails and IM's or ignored. My direct superior is either unavailable or only talks to me when there was a problem and was very confrontational about it. You are expected to try and figure things out yourself but when you get it wrong you get dragged over hot coals. I feel very alone in this job and I think COVID is only partly to blame. In order to stay on top of your workload you have to put in an inordinate amount of overtime for which you only get reimbursed holiday hours if approved by a partner during set periods, the rest of the time it's completely off the books.

headline: Not Bad for Just Coming Out School, But Not a Sustainable Career
pros:
-Become financially independent (Be smart with your money. The starting salary of an Analyst seems like a lot when you sign the contract, but it quickly evaporates if you are not budgeting. Saving/investing your money and maintaining a low key lifestyle your first 2 years will allow you to make a decision about your future at the firm after your first promotion w/o money being a factor. This is true freedom

-Lots of learning opportunities (courses, certifications, etc.) that they'll pay for

-Exposure to different industries and skillsets are a great way to prototype your interests before investing in a Masters or jumping into a more specific career path/industry
cons:
TL;DR The firm's politics take priority over efficiency making it unsustainable to start a career here and stay.

Middle-level management and upwards typically did not "grow up" in the firm (start their career with Deloitte), so they think that anyone who is starting their career with such a "great name" should shutup and appreciate what they have. These folks likely hit the consulting revolving door amongst competitors (Accenture, Booz, EY, etc.) or came from smaller firms. I really don't want to care where someone was previously. If they're a great leader and a great teammate then the labeling should not matter. But that's just it. The labeling matters to these types of leaders and their pervasive attitude about the Deloitte name makes its way down to all levels of practitioners. Deloitte has a good reputation, but we must continually work to earn that reputation day in and day out - not coast on the idea that we're great just because we're too big to fail.

Instead of focusing on the transformational aspects of building a team and serving clients, these types of leaders focus on the transactional aspects of promotion, salary, and exposure to leadership. These cultural cons trickle into every aspect of the firm - making it unsustainable for someone who values the ability to create impact, solve problems creatively, and have more autonomy over our time to stay with the firm past 2-4 years. This creates a vacuum of leadership as most who start with the firm exit before reaching management (and thus the cycle perpetuates as management is sourced from people who did not grow up in the firm).

headline: Not for everyone
pros:
There are very specific set of people who can thrive in this organisation.
Work is awesome. Pure development projects no support projects. If you are under the right leadership you can gain immense amount of experience in tech and non-tech fields.
cons:
Very unequal pay. A person who is just one year senior to me has almost double my package. We do almost the same kind of work. 
Apart for project work too much other work is there like "Firm Initiatives".
Hiring process is not good, they build too much hype around themselves causing people to think they are any better than other IT firms like TCS, Infosys, Wipro etc. the only difference between Indian IT companies and Deloitte is that Deloitte as better projects so the work is fun and Indian IT companies have only support projects mainly.

Higher management is 50-50 good and bad, still better much much better than Indian IT higher management which is sick and full of politics. There's not  too much politics here.

headline: Great for CV, bad for work life balance and health
pros: Even if short lived, my experience at Deloitte as a Big4 as always open doors for me so it paid off and i am glad i worked at Deloitte. Work ethic is high. Ideal for young professional who have the stamina to work long hours and want to learn from the best.
cons:
Zero work life balance. I worked 18h every day.... No time to eat, sleep, see friends nor gym. Overtime is the norm and expected and also working during weekend.
Pay is way below market despite the posh reputation of Deloitte and after you count the unlimited overtime more than 90h a week, your maid might make more per hour. The worse is that after scarifying my life for them and every second of my days during the work week. Senior management complained that i didn't work or answered my emails during the weekend. I was trying to rest and give my team a break. So no thank you from them but only grievance on the fact that i didn't work 18h every days of the week. Glad i left for my sanity and health. I lost a lot of weight. I was replacing another Manager who left due to a burnout. I am no surprised.

headline: No.
pros: It has potential to be easy job with flexible work schedule.
cons: The managers live in their own reality. They refuse to take accountability for their poor time management and inability to collect feedback on your clients, which accounts for your performance rating and raise, and is required every quarter. If you express any concerns about management you are scarlet-lettered, unless it's a complaint about a team member or a client (which they won't do anything anyway), it will not be acknowledged. You are more likely to be gas-lighted into thinking you have a bad attitude. They are also very tone-deaf. I wouldn't recommend this job to anyone I care about, or anyone who wants clear path progression because they can barely give you a raise or an annual review because they don't pay attention to anything..

headline: If you are from Technology background, Stay very far away.
pros:
1) Brand Value
2) Travelling to different places
3) Company helps you to reskill yourself
4) They care for communities.
5) Good to have it on resume.
cons:
1) Low salary as compared to market.
2) Deloitte hires you based on your qualifications irrespective of your skillset. If you have done MBA with a reputed college and have good communication skills, you are the right candidate. Technology Skills are secondary.
3) If you are from tech background, this is not the company for you.
4) Managers and senior managers are only presentation stars.
5) Lack of Inclusion and diversity at the top level.
6) You start feeling bias inside the company based on where you come from, how you speak. this is all transparent and yet you feel it.
7) You would see some folks getting promoted within an year and others sitting at the same level for 4-5 years. The only criteria for promotion is if a partner/senior management supports you irrespective of how you perform.
8) Partners think of themselves as gods and are literally unapproachable. 
9) Everyone is stepping on one another to move ahead. politics in each and every project to stay billable. Do not rely on words for feedback, send an email to keep record. Untrustworthy.
10) The true color of management was seen when partners got promoted whereas consultants were laid off due to covid.

headline: A horrible experience
pros: Sometimes there is free food.
cons: It's hard for me to describe how unhappy I was working at the Deloitte US Delivery Center.  I couldn't sleep at night. I would sweat through my shirt every day just sitting at my desk. I was constantly feeling a 'fight or flight' response because I felt no trust in management and was afraid they were going to harm my career to accomplish their short term goals. The work environment felt hostile to me; I found managers largely unapproachable and that my peers saw me as competition rather than a teammate.  It was hard for me to find a project that was a good fit for me, most opportunities I was offered fell way outside my area of expertise.  I never once felt appreciated working here.  I got laid off over the phone because it was raining and the guy terminating my contract didn't want to walk across the parking lot in the rain.  Overall I would say my time at Deloitte was the most challenging and unsatisfying point of my career, and I cannot recommend this job to anyone.

headline: An environment where you are nothing more than a number
pros: Great colleagues who were friendly and helpful all the way.
cons:
Before continuing, note that these comments are strictly for the business unit I worked in, not Deloitte as a whole.

I did not get a sense of direction or strategy from the partners and directors that I worked for. Actual billable work was low, resulting in horse trading with other business units where I was used as a resource for their projects. This would be fine if it was short term but this would prove to be the reality for the vast majority of my time at Deloitte.

The stakeholders of this business unit were not employee focused either. While they were never rude or unfriendly, they took no interest in their employees. Whenever they came into town (most were based out of different cities), they would not even drop by to greet my colleagues and I. It was not uncommon to watch them walk directly past me. Even when seated directly behind me, they would not even acknowledge me or say 'hello'. I initiated the greetings the first few times but seeing that this was never ever reciprocated, I can only assume they were not interested in speaking to me and stopped.

After working there for a year, I was informed of a 'raise' not by the partner of my business unit, but instead by a proxy, a partner from different business unit. And this 'raise', was for a rather insulting and disingenous amount of $1000 per annum.

When I put in my resignation letter, I was asked me a rather bizarre question: "Do you want me to ask you to stay?". He only asked me why I was leaving a day later when he was completing some paper work where the reason for my departure was needed.

headline: Valuable experience for your career
pros:
- Deloitte has many clients in different industries. The bigger sized companies and diverse client portfolio makes sure you obtain a lot of knowledge during your career here. 

- The organization has a lot of experience with new hires and will they make sure you'll be learning from day one. 

- Working here will provide you a great network of clients and coworkers. This will help you during and after your career at Deloitte.

- Deloitte has many specialized departments that you consult incase you need help.
cons:
- There is a real up-or-out culture. (you either need to grow to the next position, or you need to go)

- Salary is not so well in relation to other companies. Then again, see it as an investment. Experience here will grant you the pay in the future.

- some departments know 'high season' where you'll make a lot more hours than usual (>50). This becomes less throughout the years and you can redeem these hours in a low season as holiday (or pay out)

headline: Tread lightly.
pros:
Many smart people to work with. 

Nice to have in your resume (though employee turnover is high). 

Possibility of learning a lot of things (though not guaranteed).

Very nice offices (though overcrowded, with plans to double/triple staff within the same space).
cons:
Very poor and in many cases almost insulting salaries. Generally 15% to 30% less than the average in the region, depending on experience. Even though there is (the possibility of) an annual bonus, the amount given is not nearly enough to compensate for that difference. 

Promotion criteria are questionable. People commonly end up using job offers as leverage for a minuscule raise. 

Non-flexible 9-6 work schedule is a joke, especially when it comes to a software-related position! The typical overtime will leave you starting your personal life at night.

Off-work assignments are frequent, requests to work on public holidays and weekends are also there. No incentive is given for any kind of extra effort (requested or voluntary). 

Requesting days off and expense refunds is a nightmare. Organizing business trips is even worse. Days off, even ones requested early, are not always guaranteed up until the last moment. 

Daily work routine is often disrupted by bureaucracy and random organizational barriers. 

Many projects are merely tedious chores and may well lead to damaging your career. 

Skills are of little significance when it comes to project staffing. There's a huge technical know-how gap across seniority levels, as people flee on the 2-year mark. Most effort is carried out by juniors/young graduates who are given responsibilities 2 to 3 levels above their pay grade. Burnout and plans for the next career step are common amongst many. 

At the end of the day it's quite clear that everyone is expendable and merely a +1 in the advertised employee roster.

headline: Very sexist and unethical work culture
pros:
It is a full time job - if you are desperate for work, it is a resume filler.
If you are desperate for PR in Aus - this is a pathway (but it is a form of human trafficing)
cons:
The men are misogynistic and it is not uncommon for them to behave inappropriately around the young woman. One young woman collogue was groped by a male coworker. She made a complaint. When the partner spoke to her about it he said "have you thought about your performance, too" basically threatening her - shut up or we will manage you out!

The pay is low. Like really low. As in unlawfully low. The junior staff members are forced to work overtime without pay which brings their pay below the Australian award wage. This is unethical and unlawful. 

They have no idea what they are doing. They constantly pitch themselves to government as "expert consultants" but they consult in areas they know literally nothing about. They are "consulting" people who have worked in certain government departments for decades. For example, I was consulting for the department of education. I studied accounting and worked in accounting for years - yet I was supposed to give "expert advice" to people who have worked in education for decades? I have no idea why the government keeps hiring them.

headline: Great Work Culture and lot of flexibility
pros:
Flexibility, just get the work done, whether it is from office or home irrespective of time unless meetings are scheduled.

Average yearly increments are better than other companies especially Indian I.T companies.

Great Laptops, amazing infrastructure you'll always feel excited going to office. Good Culture in terms of Recognition or celebration.

Campus hires gets growth better than compared to lateral hire which is also a CON
cons:
Their appraisal cycle is implemented from September and performance measurements are done from April to March, as a result initially you don't see any monetary growth from the initial months that's a good way of retaining people where in you get to know afterwards. After this initial 6 months it feels like normal, and yeah the amount is generally good.

Although they make improvements to the way they do performance appraisal some become good and some become.

Most of the time, efforts are portrayed as Impactful even though when they are not. 
This happens when leadership knows you otherwise your impactful efforts are also considered as not impactful.

headline: Bad internal management and culture
pros: You have a lot of leeway to pursue specific skills. Moving around the firm project-wise is pretty easy (especially with COVID, and everyone being remote). If you are a hard worker, you can use your time at Deloitte to seriously catapult yourself into any direction you want to go.
cons:
Low quality performance management system. Basically, the Firm takes about 2 minutes per year reviewing performance snapshots submitted by your boss. It is very, very subjective. There are no hard metrics for you to complete (Client skills, Technical Skills, Project Management skills, etc). 'Grade inflation' phenomenon exists at Deloitte.: Some Managers take the 1-5 point grade process seriously, others just mark down 5's every time. This means that people internally just align themselves with managers that give 5's. 

Deloitte Partners are broadly considered to be out of touch with the ground realities. I could give many examples, but consider the fact they did a 5% layoff during COVID then IMMEDIATELY started rehiring afterward. People that were laid off even got reached out to on linkedin.

headline: Great Career Stepping Stone but Awful Place to Work Long Term
pros:
- Invests in learning and training
- Flexibility to explore different industries and projects
- Ability to travel if desired (Pre-COVID), and keep travel points 
- Opportunities to get involved within the firm and community (volunteer to lead committees and lead events)
cons:
- Severely underpaid for hours expected to work (work life balance does not exist here)
- Management/Partners only care about the bottom line and thus will sacrifice individuals compensation/bonuses 
- Performance reviews are severely minimal (only based on 3 Y/N questions), biased, delayed and inconsistent
- Extremely high turnover rate, because even though it is a fantastic addition to a resume, many Consultants have the mentality ' just survive 2 years' to get to the next step in their career. This is due to the wide-spread lack of work life balance and under-compensation.

headline: Great company
pros:
- Great culture generally (does sometimes depends which team), lots of longtime career Deloitte-rs who care about the company / brand
- Great advancement & internal secondment opportunities
- Emphasis on "People" and supporting / developing others. Colleagues I have known really do believe in this. 
- Good environment for self motivated high achievers
cons:
- Benefit allowance could be better

headline: Would not Recommend
pros:
1. People are decent and generally approachable.
2. Good for experience, though if that experience is really relevant to your future career is another matter.
cons:
1. Excessive unpaid overtime is the norm.
2. Your chargeable time is at the whims of the management and may be "asked" to modify it to keep from exceeding budgets.
3. Bad resource planning means loss of accountability and important information can happen due to the constant transition of staff and last minute changes to staffing plans.
4. Opaque performance rating system.
5. Little care is given to staff level employees in terms of development and training.
6. Trainings are ineffective and irrelevant most of the time. No respect is given to any training time and you will be expected to continue working anyways.

headline: An excellent stepping stone in your career, but shouldn't be anything more...
pros:
- Awesome perks when traveling (not applicable during covid)
- Generous expense policy (not applicable during covid)
- Great support for travel (i.e. hotlines, etc.) (not applicable during covid)
- Great opportunities to gain experience if you're eager and direct with what you can and can't do
- Great networking opportunities. You can build a great network that will provide you a number of better job opportunities outside of Deloitte when they eventually leave
- I've met some of the closest friends and mentors here
- I've met people from all different types of backgrounds and stories. Some are Ivy league MBA graduates and others didn't even earn there college degrees
cons:
- Tremendous amounts of politics 
- Awful WLB. Your leadership always expects you to perform at the next level. The norm here is to perform at a level higher than you're getting paid...think about that.
- Your "network" determines how successful you are here. Make sure you have a coach that supports you and a team that is solid
- You can easily fall into a bad network where you have abusive leadership that will keep you around and decide your next projects 
- Heavy reliance on offshore teams. While some offshore teams are solid, I think it introduces a lot of risk of things falling through the cracks and generally makes WLB awful
- Not exciting compensation growth opportunities. Unless you boomerang or threaten to leave and have a solid offer to back it up, you can perpetually be stuck in a "low" pay band
- Sometimes you'll have projects staffed with people who don't have hands-on experience with the product, but a similar one instead. This is frustrating for obvious reasons. Not every product is the same.
- The amount of time it takes for Promo cycles and paycheck increases to kick in is absurd. After the performance year, it takes an additional 6 months of reviews before your title, compensation and bonus kick in. Think about that, working a total of 18 months before you actually see your bonus or promo...
- High turnover. Consulting is obviously not for everyone, but that makes it insanely difficult to build a strong network. In 3 years of working here, 80% of the people in my network have left already
- The culture can be exhausting if you have a network that is super Type A and insists on working around the clock
- If you're not traveling, all of the good things about consulting pretty much go out the window

headline: My greatest experience

cons: Overlapping projects might give hard time for a person at entry level. But it gets better through out the years.

Which one you end up as really depends on your team, so rather than looking at general reviews, ask to speak to peers in your team to assess which bucket they sit in.

headline: Disparate siloing leads to ineffective teams
pros: Good top-level leadership, ability to work from anywhere, flexible vacation timing (needs notice instead of approval), decent pay, ability to work fewer hours if you work hard.
cons: Siloed teams means people get fired without their direct report knowing until after the person is let go, antiquated sales platform makes it hard to bring in work, very hierarchical, promotions often based on tenure rather than talent, very slow to hire new people, unhelpful onboarding process, everyone seems out to get their own thing rather than working together to a common goal. Belt has tightened over last 2 years, no more parties or dinners even before pandemic, raises and bonuses nonexistant except at promotion.

headline: Consulting is not for everyone
pros:
-Great flexibility at work
-Various types of project exposures with good learning and development opportunities
-Clients are mostly big players in the markets which bring in very interesting projects from time to time
- Some very smart and friendly people, teams tend to be energetic and young
cons:
-Working hours can be very long depending on projects
-Ask people to spend WAY too much time on other so call practice development stuff, can be fun for people with the drive but not when you are on a project working 12 hours + per day including weekends (practice development is part of your year-end review element)
-Sometimes you get place into projects by managers that do not consider your skillsets at all. Although they will sell it as "a good opportunity to learn", but from the client's standpoint, this is an unprofessional nor responsible approach. Often consultants have the capability to learn quickly but this is usually against the promises when the firm were selling the project to the client. In addition, it gets people into stressed mode, hence I said Consulting is not for everyone.

headline: Challenging and Disappointing
pros:
- Depending on the program/project, there is a culture of helpfulness that is refreshing.
- There are a small number of instances where a flat hierarchy is exemplified both internal and external (i.e. with clients).
- The benefits are great.
- Having a great "coach/counselor" sets up a fantastic upward movement in the firm.
cons:
- There is a clear culture of favoritism and micromanagement.
- If you have a strong technical background, it will not be appreciated; resulting in many scientists and engineers are leaving the firm.

headline: No Growth, No Opportunities, Don't bother working here.
pros: You might get to work on multiple projects.
cons:
You almost have no say in what projects you get assigned to.
They expect you to work at the next level for a full year, then attempt to get promoted. If you do get promoted, your pay remains the same but you get blessed with more responsibility. It's just a scam to force you to work long hours at a cheaper rate for years.
You have almost no support to switch roles or business areas.
Year end raises are horrible. 
Even though the same or even harder work is preformed, the functional only folks get bonuses.
You have no way to ask for a raise, if you bring it up, chances are they'll give you a $100 gift card and send you back to your desk.

Try not to get stuck with a generalist consulting through and through average manager as ego can come into play and they may at times give you work you're overqualified for but you're expected to feel grateful for the opportunity . Some Partners aren't generating enough business - don't get tangled in their web, they gift you with lots of low priority/ non client work which may distract you into thinking you're being productive.

headline: Good up until a point, but not exactly great
pros: Big resources, learn good skills, some of the work is challenging, and there are enough smart people to keep you stimulated. The PTO is generous and the firm pretty much shuts down during the holiday. The firm is truly Global, and we serve some big clients. Expense policy was nice when travel was a thing.
cons: Pay was good until the year before virus, now i'm staring at 3 consecutive years of little to no bump. Navigating a career at Deloitte is hard as politics reign supreme. Not too much voluntary turnover so getting promoted is becoming increasingly tough and cut throat. High work loads.

headline: Something for everyone!
pros: Deloitte truly has something for everyone. Deloitte's supportive, learning culture lends itself to a very fulfilling career.
cons: Given Deloitte's size, it's up to you to drive your own destiny. There are tons of opportunities available, but no one is going to stand over you to lead you down the best path. You've got to be comfortable with networking, trying out a few new things that may not end up being a good fit, and shifting into new opportunities as you find them.

The "bro culture" is alive and well in some departments.

headline: Good company to build your brand. Work life balance is hardly there. Bad covid response. Politics is high.
pros: Good company to build a brand and switch later. Good amount of work. Very good policies for employees. Work from home is liberal.
cons:
Massive attrition happening due to no hikes, too much work.
Promotion is a pain. Their entire appraisal revolves around making connections with managers and senior managers which basically leads to a lot of internal politics. They make you work extra in the year leading to promotion and may not necessarily promote you even if you did well as they can make you work harder the next year as well. 
Despite making a massive profit before covid and even during covid, they fired a lot of employees, gave all of us paycuts and variable pay is not given. They made the most out of it.
If you are a Senior, you have to work on initiatives over and above project work to get good rating. It basically means you work late nights or the weekends. They are not optional and come with real targets and end dates.
You are required to be compliant with a 1000 rules on a weekly basis and chances are you will miss them couples of times a year. This affects appraisal obviously.
Deloitte has a lot of crappy projects. Your career will go down the drain if you stay too long in those projects. To be fair, maybe other companies has it too.

No onsite opportunity. Period. Dont ask for it or talk about it. Doesnt matter if you build Google or space rockets. It just isn't there. Yes you might hear a story or two about some one who may have traveled. Its the exception, not the rule.

headline: Amazing experience in Risk Advisory
pros:
I started at Deloitte Luxembourg as an analyst and was promoted until manager within 5 years. Overall, I had a great time here - I made the experience, that management cares about staff, you are asked for your preferences and you are motivated to develop yourself and grow. I could make experiences working on different types of clients - from small engagements serving companies consisting of 2 employees, to big group audits in different industries with financial services being the main industry. Also I had the chance to work on different types of engagements - audit, regulatory, consulting and travel to other countries. 
In Risk Advisory a big focus is made on educating staff, there are several trainings offered per year and also I could gain several certifications. 
For me, this was a very good team to start my career. I was also quite happy with how management was dealing with the Covid crisis, we were sent to home office early on, and I could feel that management is caring about their people - even if in the beginning there was a lot of uncertainty.
cons: As I was working on audit engagements, busy season hits hard every year - however this is as it is expected in this line of work and there are also possibilities to take on less clients if desired. Overall, the experience that someone makes depends a lot on the team and leadership of the team you are working in - for Risk Advisory team I cannot tell many other cons.

headline: MBA Freshers - BEWARE
pros:
Ample certifications and learning opportunities available to techies.
Good work culture. Senior management is considerate of performance and bonus.
cons:
B-School freshers, be very careful of joining Deloitte USI (USI is US back end office) which is a separate entity from Deloitte India.

If you are not inducted into strategy role, you will be placed amongst software engineers, you will be compared with them and thus, you will be expected to outperform them AS SOFTWARE ENGINEER.

Internal mobility is a very rare and depends on your graduation and pre-MBA experience.

IIM graduates have been seen working as testers (QA) on RPA projects.

After 2 years of working in this role, switch to a different firm in a desired role becomes extremely difficult.

headline: Misleading Job Description
pros:
The culture is honestly amazing. I joined during a pandemic as well so that's a pretty big statement considering I never went to the office. You'll feel supported and everyone is really friendly (including partners).
Great work life balance.
cons:
The risk advisory position I took in Technology Digital Risk was mis sold. It is essentially IT Audit, with the 'chance' of doing advisory work 5+ years down the line if you're lucky (note its about an 80/20 split between IT audit and advisory work anyway). I doubt the advisory work is interesting and worth 5 years of your career regardless.
No career progression outside of the firm. If you stay long enough, you'll only get Internal Audit opportunities at mid and big size firms. It pigeon-holes you completely.
As a reference point, a few other grads reached out to me when they heard I was leaving as they were all feeling the same way about the job - seems like everyone is duped into this role in a way.

headline: They do not care about laterals| DO NOT JOIN
pros: The only pro is if a kind US SM (USI SMs are glorified Managers swimming in a small pond where no one can challenge them) takes you under their wing
cons:
This is one of the worst managed practices I have ever seen in my life-
1 . The appraisal system is so random that they will find weird excuses to not promote you or give you a raise.
2. They expect you to do unpaid labor in the form of Firm Initiatives after your regular project work- and yes you are required to perform really well at those to get any chances of a decent raise. Apparently, just being good at what you were hired to do is not good enough
3. Quality of work- USI team is treated like a backend dump. Expect work around secondary research mostly. Very limited to no client interface- in some cases they do not even introduce USI teams to clients or just call them out as our "research support"

headline: Worst and unethical  HR

headline: Robots wanted
pros: Prestige. Line in a resume. One way to learn how not to lead.
cons: Micro managers. Company who hires smart driven people only to treat them like robots who’s thoughts don’t count - don’t think just do should be their mantra. Partners who fail to lead. They knowingly hire Partners with histories of sexual harassment. Only people who rise to Partner are those who are willing to play the game and stab each other in the back. They fire people while on maternity leave. One Partner quote on quote said “women have know place in the workplace”. Other Partners have told woman in their team the clients only see them for their looks. Criminally low pay.

headline: Lots of career opportunities but at a high cost
pros: ability to take on a lot of high-impact work early in your career, overall benefits and salary are fairly competitive
cons: horrible work-life balance -- depending on your project you could easily be working 12+ hours a day and on weekends, upper management overcommits to timelines with clients without consulting those below them, every project is 1-2 individuals short, weekly travel (pre-covid), requirements to do additional firm initiative work in addition to major project demands, lots of guilt-tripping if you want to try to find a new project or change your role, senior managers generally only care about your career development if it aligns with their interests

headline: Good Work and Lots of It
pros: Interesting, motivating people, lots of company support, and part of the job description is doing lots of different initiatives so you're never bored.
cons: LOTS of work, expected 45-55 hours/week minimum. Part of your annual review depends on firm initiatives, is hard to juggle client work and internal initiatives as a junior practitioner. You have to get VERY good at protecting your bandwidth because upper management has no problem asking more and more out of you until you burn out and even after.

headline: Avoid like the plague

- Highly motivated group of people

- A great variety of clients/ industries/ challenges
cons:
- You will have NO personal life, zero, zilch, nada. Any commitments outside of work are seen as a distraction

- Very few people end up working on projects they enjoy/ are a good fit for... 99.99% of the time, you will be put on horrendously under-staffed projects in industries you've never worked in before, and with managers you absolutely hate

- People are terrified to speak up about anything, and when they do, they are shown the backdoor and promptly pushed out

headline: Severe Understaffing and Unprofessional Treatment of Employees
pros: Benefits are great (although not the best in the industry), and they offer a 5 weeks of PTO as a new employee (but good luck taking it).
cons: Exploitative work schedules due to severe understaffing. Leadership expects you to operate as a professional with a shoestring budget for staffing. They don't have nearly enough staff to do the basic functions of the job, but when you can't keep your work afloat in 70+ hour weeks, they tell you that you don't know how to prioritize or you aren't putting out *fill in the level* work. Leadership believes the way to resolve this is to have more happy hour and zoom chat activities which are attended by just a few. Employees are suffering with mental health issues and extreme exhaustion due to the pressure, long hours, and lack of balance. Deloitte doesn't like using "work/life balance," trading that instead for "work/life integration," because they want you to integrate your work into your personal time. Self preservation is frowned upon in action, but they'll tell you how important wellness is to the company. They tell you to take your PTO, but good luck trying to find someone to cover you when you're out. Management says all the right things while also saying all the wrong things. Because they talk out of both sides of their mouths, employees are left confused, gaslit, and invalidated. That's how they skirt any real accountability for their behavior.

headline: Where Demand Often Outweighs Reward
pros:
- You will work with incredibly talented people. 
- The opportunities to access a breadth of industries and skills are unparalleled. 
- Cultivate a network of colleagues and clients that will last a lifetime.
cons:
- Work/life balance is talked about, marketed, and trumpeted from the rooftops - but seldomly encouraged.

- If your career goals and Deloitte's goals for you are misaligned you can expect an uphill battle to be who you want to be, vs. Becoming what the firm wants you to be.

- You need to be your own advocate, which is challenging if you are at any level below partner, as your needs rarely trump the needs of the firm.

- Good work is often punished with increased workload/responsibility as the only "reward".

headline: The best work experience I never has

cons: Not to much career development for the UK office

headline: Best position I ever had
pros: I came to Deloitte later in life, after many years at a big systems integrator. The caliber of the people is fantastic - in terms of their intelligence, work ethic and personability. The clients and projects are interesting and engaging. I particularly enjoyed the ability to mix strategy projects with implementation projects. The Strategy & Analytics group is a big growth area for the firm and its clients, so there is always a new challenge ahead.
cons: There's no doubt that Deloitte is a highly competitive environment. Everybody is ranked against their peers, and those rankings are the most important factor in bonuses and promotions. You may see that as a positive or a negative. For me it was more of a negative since I don't have aspirations to progress to partner.

headline: Enjoyable place to work, but pays under market rate
pros:
Great people in the studios
Good diversity
Lots of team work
Willing to hire people with non-traditional career path
Great vacation time
Nice variety of projects and freedom to pick the kind of projects you enjoy
Lots of opportunities to learn and advance your skill set
Nice culture

I think it’s a great place for anyone early in their career to get a big name on their resume and get lots of projects and experience under their belt.
cons:
The pay is not competitive for the field and area.

The recruiters are crafty liars. They tell people the level given will be based on experience, then give them a level 4, which they don’t mention is actually the LOWEST level despite sounding mid-level. They claim you can get bonuses at the end of the year, but don’t mention level 4s are not eligible for bonuses.

The levels seem to be partly based on your gender - multiple women were a level way below their actual skill level and multiple men were leveled too high. They know it - management would discuss the problem, but then claim they just couldn’t fix it. They still expect you to work at your actual skill level, not the lower one they hired you at. When they do promote you to a higher level, the salary increase is barely enough to match inflation.

Work-life balance is sometimes not ideal, but not atypical for consulting.

headline: Won't recommend for freshers
pros: Good infrastructure, laptop, flashy merchandise
cons:
I was placed in Deloitte USI during my campus placements. They changed the offer to spot offer after placing us thereby making sure that we wouldn't sit for any other company. They had first promised us internships but took them out of the offer at the last minute.

The package we got was pretty bad as well. For some verticals, you're stuck with the same salary for 3+ years before you can climb up the ladder.

They didn't give me my location of choice and I had to wait for one whole year before I could get relocated to the city of my choice. 

For freshers coming from campus placements, they don't consider your career aspirations into consideration and randomly assign you a technology line and there's literally no way of changing it.

Now coming to the actual work:
1. There is a huge bench and employees aren't adequately staffed into projects
2. Freshers are given a very rigorous 30-day training at the start of the job but are given very basic work once they're assigned to projects, like documentation, and it just might happen that by the time you have to start working on the technology, you won't really remember anything since it's been so long since you have actually practiced anything that you have to go through the training all by yourself
3. The work hours are very long and the work is very demanding. There are very few seniors who actually groom the freshers on-the-job so you're kind of left on your own to catch up - which can become overwhelming
4. The culture is pretty toxic. Nobody really cares about the other person in the team and there's a lot of politics among the leadership that affects literally everyone working under them. There are a lot of office relationships that hamper your work relationships.

headline: Just a brand name - Very Low Compensation
pros: Work Culture and Environment, some managers and senior managers are really good to work with
cons:
1. Very low compensation compared to Indian or Multinational competitors and firms
Despite of booming business and revenue, compensation is below 5% for top performers and highly appreciated employees. This is not only for 2020, 2021.
Meagre hikes of 10% given in last couple of years.
2. Just a brand name
We all work for a living and Deloitte just stands out for its brand name. In terms of compensation for the brand, it really lags behind. Do not opt for this brand name vs a high paying job.
3. Too much politics and favouritism in some offerrings. It is not as clean as it looks like or is portrayed. Opportunities and benefits are only meant for the favourites.
4. Work from home is not supported by all projects.
Leadership of many projects still have the old mindset of lack of trust on employees working remotely. Their mindset may impact you eventually in year ends even if you are working remotely for genuine reasons.
5. Real long working hours. Expect to work 12 hours a day minimum on any project. Additionally you are expected to do firm activities for which you need to invest time from your weekends or overwork on weekdays outside project hours. All this for a meagre rise of 5-10% per year.

headline: Do not go if it is USDC!!!
pros: Good network opps and great projects if you have a good network with core Deloitte staff
cons:
Never ever go to USDC. From my experience, USDC is a substandard culture of what we call Deloitte consulting. 
People are paid way less money for the same amount of work done as compared to core consultants in core talent model.
Please note that core deloitte talent model is where you usually travel 80% and meeting amazing people unlike USDC.
After joining based on the sponsorship and brand name, I was regretting it every second after I joined Deloitte.
Please please think twice before joining USDC specially internationals.
You will find substandard people and i felt hell lot of a difference between USDC and core deloitte. Beware!
For information, USDC and core are different talent models in which USDC is more tech focused and core is more traditional consulting with lot of travel.

headline: Great Company, Great Culture
pros:
-Better work-life balance than typical Big 4. 40 -45 hour work weeks are norm
-PTO, benefits, well-being subsidy, CPA study materials provided, other bonuses throughout year
-Very friendly & collaborative culture
-Minimal travel involved to clients, all work based out of USDC office in Gilbert
cons:
-Busy season work
-Starting pay is lower than most Big 4
-Lack of consistency with clients & lots of juggling multiple clients at same time
-Not a lot of consistency with the team you work with, managers/seniors are different with each client, always adapting to team preferences/norms

headline: What a nightmare!
pros: The pay was good... sort of... Once you start working there and realize the mental hell, office politics, clicky drama, and ridiculous workload senior managers dump on you the pay was not that great.
cons: Horrible place to work! To use the term high stress would be a complete understatement. Senior managers just dump work on you, no training, no support. Definitely witnessed a better work environment for men but even then I saw male employees be treated really badly. People there on all levels only care about themselves and no one speaks up to protect team members. It is a culture of everyone for themselves. Just awfully place honestly, all they care about is money and the client. They pretend to care about talent but actually only care about the client/money.

-Lower level employees do very little value add work that will be useful in their future careers. 
-Low emphasis on technology skills needed in today's job market place. PPT zombies.

Poor pay for the past couple of years

headline: Had potential, but doesn't stack up
pros: It was cool at first to be able to achieve what you want and go your own way. Figure out what will work best for you as an individual. Lot's of smart, fun people. Free snacks were cool.
cons: So it turns out you generally aren't working with those smart, fun people. Deloitte is all about individual performance and nothing more. This type of performance management breeds politics and shady business. It's all about getting on a project and getting as many client billable hours as possible; Nothing else matters to this business. Literally nothing. If you complain that you're working too many hours, you'll probably be discretely "separated" from the company. If you try to follow the core value of "elevate the human experience" and attempt to elevate the experience of your teammates, you'll be reprimanded for not getting enough client billable hours and most likely be "separated" from the company. If you have big ideas, you'll get no interest from management; Okay, maybe you'll get a little support and a lot of jaded, "good luck"s thrown your way. Not worth it. People here are under-appreciated, under-paid, under-utilized, and can do better. There are plenty of other companies with a stronger culture and better core values to work for. I swear, I'm not disgruntled. I just know Deloitte is trying to hire for a lot of roles right now even though they just laid thousands of people off last year. Don't fall into the trap.

headline: Worst Experience

- Inconsiderate partners
- Narcissistic management
- Demanding of personal time (beyond a +10 hour day and weekends)
- No reward for hard work (Hard work lines managers and partners through bonuses only)
- Not comparable to Deloitte around the world (poor staff well being, lack of HR intervention etc)
- Ineffective and untrustworthy HR manager (no sense of confidentiality)

headline: Good atmosphere, apathetic management
pros: I loved my coworkers and the atmosphere was always fun without damage to productivity.
cons: All the pros are greatly overshadowed by management's inability to provide a secure environment. Oppressive supervision, condescending tones, inadequate training, and overly strict policies work against employees. The hourly pay is only adequate if you stay as a teller, but they provide little incentive to move up in the company. Head tellers only make a dollar with a laughable cap on commission; not worth three times the responsibility. Favoritism runs rampant and it's clear they hire a certain type of person. They also will NOT work with your schedule and will manipulate you against taking time off.

headline: Tread Carefully
pros:
• People are genuinely nice. Great team spirit and enthusiasm for learning and doing the best for the client.
• Excellent place to start as a graduate - great exposure, chance to deliver, progression will be monitored and you will be recognised and rewarded if you are good enough.
cons:
• Benefits - Holiday, Pension, Health insurance is poor.
• If you have not grown through the levels it can be hard to break into the clique especially as an outsider hired in. 
• Difficult for them to meet any preference to work in an industry, with a certain technology, in a certain type of role. Clients needs, and who is available and can passably fill the open role is the main priority.
• Exposure to Deloitte in the US - as clichéd as you would expect. Less about delivery.

cons: Poor annual raises (2-4%) and low bonuses (~$3k) (for Services), limited growth opportunity within Services, unpredictable hours, culture of hard work and excellence often goes unrewarded, currently focusing more on expanding staff than rewarding existing staff.
