headline: Things chnaged
pros:
* Great Upper Level Leadership. Good on the floor presence 
* Open Door Policy. You can walk up to any Senior person on the floor. No calling anyone sir
* Good Flexibility if you're in the right project
* Has a good communication gym and physical gym
* Great people all around in general. Didn't find too much of politics here
* Year long office events keeping the workplace active (as long as your project allows you to have time to participate)
* Most projects have a budget for team outings and parties and its a great way to boost morale and have fun
* If you're an extrovert and are good at networking, you can easily grow in the firm
* Office infrastructure is good
* Pre-covid had a decent pay hike and normalization does happen over time 
* Currently opened a mobile reimbursement policy for reimbursing 25k on select mobile phones
* Good Training programs have started in the last 1-2 years. They are getting employees trained in multple fronts
* Free Udemy access and other training portals
cons:
* Evaluation for hikes/bonuses happens for Mar-Mar. But is rewarded only by August-September forcing employees to wait for 6 months for the work they have already done. Seems like a cheap attempt to prevent people from leaving
* Work Life Balance has not been good once Covid hit because of bad planning from upper management. Pre-covid it all depended on the project and your luck. Some had it bad but in general it was ok. Post Covid most projects had bad work life balance 
* If you aren't an extrovert, growing and getting opportunities is difficult in the organization. The company is built on the one word - networking and it is critical for you to grow. 
* The down side of networking is that if you do a good job, you will never be released from a long term project even if requested for. It is hard to get other opportunities. 
* If you are a Senior Consultant and above you are expected to do a lot of extra activities (Firm Activities). This is over and above any project work. If you don't this directly impacts your year end badly. Until last year it used to be for all employees. 
* Didn't treat employees fairly during Covid times. Many people were asked to resign and other good performers were put into PIP because of utilization and Firm Initiatives and not lack of performance in their client work

headline: Things chnaged
pros:
* Great Upper Level Leadership. Good on the floor presence 
* Open Door Policy. You can walk up to any Senior person on the floor. No calling anyone sir
* Good Flexibility if you're in the right project
* Has a good communication gym and physical gym
* Great people all around in general. Didn't find too much of politics here
* Year long office events keeping the workplace active (as long as your project allows you to have time to participate)
* Most projects have a budget for team outings and parties and its a great way to boost morale and have fun
* If you're an extrovert and are good at networking, you can easily grow in the firm
* Office infrastructure is good
* Pre-covid had a decent pay hike and normalization does happen over time 
* Currently opened a mobile reimbursement policy for reimbursing 25k on select mobile phones
* Good Training programs have started in the last 1-2 years. They are getting employees trained in multple fronts
* Free Udemy access and other training portals
cons:
* Evaluation for hikes/bonuses happens for Mar-Mar. But is rewarded only by August-September forcing employees to wait for 6 months for the work they have already done. Seems like a cheap attempt to prevent people from leaving
* Work Life Balance has not been good once Covid hit because of bad planning from upper management. Pre-covid it all depended on the project and your luck. Some had it bad but in general it was ok. Post Covid most projects had bad work life balance 
* If you aren't an extrovert, growing and getting opportunities is difficult in the organization. The company is built on the one word - networking and it is critical for you to grow. 
* The down side of networking is that if you do a good job, you will never be released from a long term project even if requested for. It is hard to get other opportunities. 
* If you are a Senior Consultant and above you are expected to do a lot of extra activities (Firm Activities). This is over and above any project work. If you don't this directly impacts your year end badly. Until last year it used to be for all employees. 
* Didn't treat employees fairly during Covid times. Many people were asked to resign and other good performers were put into PIP because of utilization and Firm Initiatives and not lack of performance in their client work

headline: Deloitte India lacks behind its USI counterpart
pros:
Pros in Deloitte India
1. Direct interaction with clients
2. Hands on experience with multiple technologies
3. Strong collaboration with other Deloitte entities like Deloitte USI , DELOITTE middle East
cons:
Cons of Deloitte India
1. Quite unstructured in terms of technical skills and capabilities. They hire or loan resources based on the capabilities required for projects won and try to manage with resources having little experience.
2. Pay structure is not up to the mark. 
3. Performance review process is quite centralised and depends to a large extent on yoir relationship with higher management.
4. Indian projects are mostly small in size with limited opportunities

headline: No room for growth, toxic management
pros: Young team, hence, easy to gel in. Very much like college environment.
cons:
This review is specific to Fusion Managed Services(FMS) within the cyber offering.
1) Good to start, for the initial 6 months, but then the learning curve flattens. Very limited to no opportunity to grow and learn.
2) The leadership in India lacks vision and transparency. 
3) No meaningful feedback on performance. The team is super big in size and working on minimal profits, so more than skills, bureacracy works in getting appraisals. Not writing from a bitter space, was promoted in the very first year.
4) Shift work. People continue working in shifts for years at end, without any improvement, leaving them choice to quit the firm. Very high attrition rate.
5) Very limited budget for trainings. 
6) Employee Wellbeing is non-existent at the ground level.
7) Salary for cyber in general market is shooting. Deloitte is stuck at old levels.
8) New campus hires are being brought in at the same salary level as the existing employees with 2-3 years of experience.

headline: Good profile. But bad management and long working hours mess it up
pros: Good company to have in your CV once you are out of college. Knowledgeable colleagues/ seniors. Some of the organizational policies before the pandemic were very good.
cons: Long working hours with upto 16-17 hrs of work during busy period. There is little to no personal life and even that is not adequate to impress your already biased bosses. The salary is peanuts for the amount of work expected. There is always a wellness survey conducted every year. But they don't take the results seriously. They are only obsessed with billing hours.

headline: Tired, Staff Shortage, but Great Knowledge
pros: Working here as an auditor allow you to have better understanding of the accounting standards are. The managers are willing to help you explain, and provide training. Love the office, very neat. But very serious surrounding. Sometimes no laughter at all.
cons: Due to covid, Deloitte now has shortage of staff to work in a particular engagement. From 10 staff needed, only 5 are assigned because only 2 are available. So the work becomes very heavy and rushing. Tiring. Need to work extra hours with no OT. Thats just how it is.

headline: If you know how to play the game and set boundaries, it's a beneficial place to work
pros:
- Deloitte invests a lot of money into professional development & training
- You have access to a broad range of opportunities
- [Pre-covid] Tons of travel perks
- Compensation was reasonable
cons:
- If you don't know how to set boundaries, you can burn out easily
- The performance evaluation process was more heavily based on the power of your network than work ethic
- There was a lot of performative diversity & inclusion work being done but deep down I don't think they were moving the needle much on making progress

*All cons were cons that you would experience at any company so I still would recommend the company to others

headline: Exhausted!!!
pros: Benefits and policies. Inclusion and diversity is good. But please read the cons which I am desperate to share to those who is about to join Deloitte. Instead pick other service based companies and thank me later.
cons:
I am not a guy who gives a damn about others but here I am. So you can consider it seriously.

No work life balance and I mean it. 95% of the projects. I have been in critical projects before with other firms during my 6 years of experience, but here you can't even imagine how that looked like but again some projects are good though. You have to extremely lucky to be in those projects.
They do stand what they talk.
Never care about your well being though they preach they are doing their best.
Some mean managers managing some projects spoils the reputation of the company.
You need to exaggerate your work in appraisals. How good you show off is what matters at the end of the day.

headline: Good place to start career, but unsure about staying long-term
pros: Learning from smart people, flexibility to try different client projects, benefits like $500 wellbeing subsidy has been great. Travel perks were also pretty good before COVID. Once you find a good network, they can be very supportive throughout your career
cons:
Very network-based, and performance is basically evaluated on how much your manager likes you and your ability to stay staffed on client projects. Being evaluated on a scatterplot of your peers (all of which who have managers that evaluate their talent differently) is really misleading and honestly not helpful to my development.

Having long hours is standard, like most consulting firms. You have to suss out which partners / SMs tend have more intense projects and pursue staffing opportunities accordingly. Even though it has been acknowledged that people are feeling burnt out during the pandemic from constant Zoom meetings, nothing has really changed significantly to fix it.

Also, GSAP is a lot more selective than in the past, even though it's marketed heavily when recruiting candidates. I recently found out I wasn't eligible because my performance wasn't "exceptional", even though I feel like I went above and beyond over the past 2 years, so that's extremely demotivating. Compensation is relatively average

headline: Good start to a career
pros:
- Vast majority are very nice/friendly people and fairly approachable, including partners/directors/managers
- Good job security in Audit as often understaffed + high staff turnover (also a con)
- Very fast paced learning and growth. You get to work with/at big listed companies and their upper management.
- Plenty of support for getting Chartered Accounting qualification
cons:
- Salary could always be better
- Depending on resourcing and project, workloads can be very heavy. Some may find it difficult to say no to extra work.
- Learning curve can feel very steep up to the first 6-9 months. Also a pro because you learn a lot on the job, but this can be demotivating if you feel you aren't being useful at first.

headline: Worst place to work! (Do not work here if you're a normal human)
pros: Big name, looks good on the CV (for people who don't know any better). Women generally protected to achieve gender targets.
cons: Toxic culture based on fear, bullying and intimidation. People with empathy and a kind nature will ultimately be eliminated. Work delivered is usually substandard, overpriced and the company has a ruthless focus on maximizing profit margin. Archaic IT systems with rigid adherence to inflexible processes required. Bureaucratic and clicky. Better than average salaries seduce many employees to take big mortgages who then become trapped in Deloitte's toxic consulting hell. If you want to learn the cruel, brutal side of human nature or are a psychopath please apply.

headline: Good, challenging expereince
pros:
- You'll always be learning; rarely are you the smartest person at the lunch table
- Lots of opportunities to work on
- Good talent development model
- Solid benefits; generous PTO
- If you work in DD, the managers are all technical/creative practitioners who know how to lead and mentor
cons:
- If you're in DD, working on Big D projects will feel "different"
- Talent development and performance review models between DD and Big D seem to different greatly, which seems problematic if you're in DD but staffed on on something in Big D
- Lots of burnout. Long, sometimes very long, hours on some projects
- Tough to stand out in a very social environment, especially as an introvert
- Attracting, retaining, and promoting diversity is not a particular strength in many parts of the firm

headline: Great company, culture, career advancement, and outlook, but pay could be better

cons: Pay on the Federal side could be much better. Hearing about fresh graduates coming in at $80k with $10-20k signing bonuses on the commercial side while a high-performing senior consultant on the federal side with 5 years of experience makes $85-100k with maybe a $5-10k bonus is a very bad look.

headline: Great place to learn but no WLB and low salary
pros:
Great place to learn and grow consulting skills (people management, sales, delivery).
Lot of flexibility about how you manage your time and lots of days off given by the firm.
Mostly smart and supportive people.
Decent bonus.
cons:
Toronto-centric, all decisions are taken by the national leadership there. 
You usually work for multiple partners at the time who have no clue (and frankly dont care) about what you are required to do by another partner.
High expectations in term of sales and delivery and people management and firm development (recruitment, white paper, internal opportunities,...). Deloitte has progressively eliminated all unbillable jobs (HR, sales, recruitement,...) so it is expect that every M/SM support the firm with these unbillable tasks which still have to be done obviously.
Salary is below market these days and this is not going to be fixed.
Focusing more and more on large deals and “run” rather than “imagine” and “deliver” which is not exciting work whatsoever. More outsourcing as well. Slowly becoming Accenture.

headline: Decent Workplace
pros:
Pros: 

-Gives lots of opportunities for you to look for other contracts/opportunities to grow
-Lots of networking events for you to participate/free food
-Bonus spread out accordingly
-Well being subsidy
cons:
-Depending on what engagement you are on, the team can be clinquish (the project I was on was literally so cliquish that they know if you want to be promoted, but they don't provide any guidance whatsoover) 
-A lot of process to go through to transition into another engagement (whatever you do, have a CLEAR and DOCUMENTED conversation regarding your transition date or they will drag it out) 
-Wish some information are laid out and full disclosure
-Wish travel/mileage and parking is reimbursable

headline: Ageism is rampant
pros: Work life balance, training and benefits
cons: If you are over 40, the younger, more senior people that grew up in Deloitte after college committ ageist acts without remorse. I witnessed people in their 40s and 50s deliver incredible solutions, on time and on budget to then receive moderate ratings in their reviews. For some of these people, their contributions saved young project managers from disaster to then have the same PM give high ratings to defect riddled, slow practitioners that were in their 20s and early 30s. It is ridiculous and disgusting. Deloitte's to 100 employer status is an illusion and not deserved. Spent 4 years there and left for a better job, salary and title, never looking back.

headline: Output valued more than employees,  toxic culture, does not live up to prestige & branding
pros:

-plenty of trainings (online and in person)
cons:
-constantly being compared to other analysts (even on scatterplot each performance review) 
-working longer hours than necessary due to poor management/leadership skills 
-unethical way of selling projects (overselling work)

If you are a human with empathy, this place will not be an easy one to work at. The culture is all about outshining one another and the work and output is valued more than the human being. I have trauma after working at this place.

headline: Be careful before accepting the offer
pros: Brand image on the CV
cons:
Tailored for Partner's.

You're dreaming if you're expecting to grow financially with them...

You will be expected to do a LOT beyond your customer engagement (up to 20 hours a week and sometimes more) with very little recognition. The joke is that you will hear a lot of music about work life balance...

Huge focus on a single subjectively negative appraisal over 10s of positive client recognized impacts. This will also impact your promotion and salary increase, if it ever happen (hope you will not be shocked with 50£ and 100£ hikes)

If you have an alternative offer, please do not overvalue Deloitte as a brand or company. Never take their offer if it's not better than the competition as you will be squeezed for every single penny you will be getting.

Be very careful with the HR and recruitment team, they are expert MANIPULATORS. They will put every pressure on you to make you feel like you will be losing a lot by no immediately accepting an offer that is not aligned with what you want. The recruitment process might take 9-12 months and they will almost seem to be proud of it, but they will ask you to think over a scrap offer overnight hinting that they have a lot of applicants waiting for the role...

Not aligned to what other consultancies do, You will be expected to pay you lunch, drinks and coffees even if you are travelling to the south pole to deliver a client project.

Don't expect to have the right support to grow. You will be thrown in the middle of the pacific and expected to reach California by yourself. Very poor coaching and average/limited training offering.

Few of my colleagues reported that they have seen a last minute change to the offer bringing the salary and the grade to lower levels while they have been promised that they will be able to get it back in 1 year and as you might be thinking: Dream on; no one of them have been able to get what he expected in day 1 after the 1st year. I came to infer that this is some sort of practice to source high caliber profiler for lower salaries, get them into clients for very high rates (sometime 2 grades higher) while they will never feel that on their salary, promotion or even recognition.

PLEASE, be careful of what choice you're making before joining. I sincerely hope you will not be deeply disappointed and (hate yourself and) regret the day you accepted their offer.

headline: Disappointing & Mediocre Firm
pros:
-COLLEAGUES: Many colleagues I've worked on my projects are some of the best people I have the pleasure of working with
-PROJECT VARIETY: Firm is very large and has its hands in nearly all industries around the world. If one is able to navigate the bureaucracy, the variety of projects that one can do is immense
cons:
-PROJECT STAFFING: Since the firm is very large, many of the project staffing teams are overburdened. This leads to an over-reliance on networking and informal staffing to find a project that is of interest and right for your skillset. 
-PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT: The Performance management system factors for which one is evaluated is very opaque and is highly dependent on the partners input on whether they know and like the practitioner. To wit, I've known colleagues who appeared excellent on the evaluation factors which are visible to them but have been evaluated poorly, or even fired in a few cases, due to little partner support.
-COMPENSATION & BENEFITS: Compensation is lower than what other strategy consulting firms offer and, while Deloitte offers a 401k match, the firm only matches ~1.5% of salary of which is 100% vested at 4 years.

headline: Fair Company but Resistant & Slow to Change
pros:
- Employee benefits (Pension, Maternity etc)

- Efforts to instill company culture, with events etc. for new joiners and junior staff.
cons:
- Resistant to any change with a 'this is how it is done here' mentality.

- Hierarchical; little interface between junior and senior staff with a 20th century culture.

- Long working hours (expected) but dull and with no incentives to work effectively (the expectation of hours worked has little to do with actual output of individuals. Perceptions of commitment are time rather than task orientated).

headline: Career Pathing and development
pros: Deloitte's selling point for young hires starting a career is that there is a clear development path and steps to promotion if you fit into the mold of a consultant. Someone that can handle both the technical and functional aspects of the work while having excellent social skills. If you can succeed in that space the sky is the limit here, if your limit is to one day be a Deloitte partner, or make it to Manager before leaving for industry.
cons: Culture is tough in consulting generally and Deloitte is no exception. Firstly the culture is hegemonic and there is a prevailing groupthink dynamic. However, there is no immediate harm in going your own way and being yourself, but the people who advance tend to "drink the Kool-Aid" and have a similar view for how work should be sold and delivered. Furthermore, burnout is part of the bottom line calculation, this industry can grind you down if you are not careful and if you don't developed a good internal network.

headline: At Deloitte, Whatever They Say They Value is What They Punish in Fact
pros: Salaries are good, and you won't have to be bothered by things like human relationships, romance, or family, because you will have no opportunity whatever to pursue any of those old-fashioned things. You may as well tell your family right now that you won't be home for the holidays. Or weekends. Or very likely retirement, because you're not going to live that long.
cons: As a transfer pricing senior manager in the Tysons, VA offices of Deloitte, I found myself immersed in a toxic culture of aloofness, narcissism, paranoia, and despair. The partners generally appear to hate one another, and treat each other as rivals. One in particular suffers obvious symptoms of mental disturbance, most likely narcissistic personality disorder. (Example: Her standard engagement letter actually includes braggadocio about her years as a Ph.D. student and her professional awards. What striking insecurity!) More generally, there is an endless rhetorical barrage about the importance of expressing honest disagreement and respect for diversity of opinion. That is nothing but institutional gaslighting. They are trying to get you to deny the reality that the only way to succeed is to agree with management, no matter how unethical, disrespectful, or ignorant their decisions might be.

headline: The people make the place!
pros:
- Supervisors that care about you as a human.
- Transparency is a fundamental part of this organization and it shows.
- We take our own medicine and are constantly looking for ways to improve. Things are always changing based on feedback and that’s the way it should be!
- Opportunities to explore different career paths and stretch your strengths (not the things you’re good at, the things that bring you energy).
- You will be assigned (or choose) a coach that is quite literally there to help you grow as a professional and help you navigate the firm. It’s nice having someone that you can talk to about your educational shortfallings without fear of retribution.
cons:
- Only place lacking transparency is the compensation model
- The organization is so big that the duplicity of work is apparent for internal initiatives. So many different groups within the organization are working to achieve the same goal without collaboration.

headline: Consider your goals before getting in
pros: Good working environment, smart and professional colleagues
cons:
Crazy working hours. In tax dept it is implicitly assumed that no overtime will be granted. You should expect to work around 60+ hrs a week in busy season in the consultant level and receive no bonus for your extra hours. 

With the COVID-19 situation, there are more reasons for higher levels to cut bonus and perks.

If you're financially stable and can manage a salary of 8-12 mil VND a month, Deloitte is worth to experience because in exchange you can grow tremendously.

In terms of culture, I think Deloitte is the most SOE-like among the 4 big. So a bit of diplomacy is often, if not always, essential.

headline: Best of the Best
pros: The positive culture that encompasses this company is unreal. Everyone is very understanding, accommodating, and truly makes you want to be your best self at work. I was a little worried before starting that Deloitte was going to be a mind-numbing corporate job (like my internship at another company), but I am so happy to say that that worry went away very quickly after starting 6 months ago.
cons: There are definitely some days that are very long and filled with work and things to do, but the culture is very supportive of taking time off, taking small wellness breaks throughout the day (I try to go on a walk or go to the gym around lunch), and that is very much welcomed with working from home because everyone feels themselves burning out at some point. However, there are times where you have to put the client deliverables first and sacrifice extra hours worked. For me, that was an expectation of mine before joining the firm, maybe from working at a country club in college, but I have some peers that were not expecting that when they first started and had to acclimate a bit.

headline: Crumbling block of mess
pros:
They provide excellent experience of modern age slavery.
 If you are wondering what working in sweat shop feels like definitely recommend joining this place.
cons:
Managers and partners are not concerned about what are your skillsets, as far as they see a body that has functional limbs, they sell you to clients.
You would be sitting at client location for ages, where clients would treat you like their personal slave since Deloitte charges exorbitant amounts per resource.
Once on-boarded to the organization and a project, your managers and senior would just vanish, so no chance or scope of having any conversations around career growth, progress, they would deliberately turn down your meeting requests, so no feedbacks on your performance.

headline: Remarkable career growth
pros: I worked at Deloitte Banglore for 2years and it was the best experience of my career. Though the culture is tight and pushes employees to work more by assigning many responsibilities, the experience you gain in Deloitte is almost equal to a b-school experience. Very good for people who are at earlier stages of their career.
cons: Poor work life balance. At many instances I have seen leads and seniors working extended hours and on weekends just like a normal practice. And it won't be appreciated or like you are taking additional responsibility , it will just your regular task.

headline: Great training ground for recent grads
pros: For recent grads, its a great place to get trained in the business world. You get exposed to different problems in different industries and work with different teams to solve them. You learn how to think on your feat and solve problems by thinking through implications for different stakeholders.
cons: They will 100% pigeon hole you into a practice that essentially does brain-numbingly boring work IF you don't fight for what you want to do. Beware, following the "career path" of your choice will 100% impact your promotion cycles, bonuses, raises etc.

headline: Good starting place
pros:
It is a big company with diverse people, which lead to great development in my audit journey. 
They also provide sufficient amount of training to understand the work flow better to provide quality and excellence over service.
Excellent for building audit experience.
cons:
The company is too work orientated and may on certain occasion put aside the needs of the employee to ensure certain work is done.
Depending on department or manager your work can be slanted or grown, however it is important to know the difference and to have a manager that is encouraged on helping you grow.
Hours are as usual long as accustomed to audit, but my main issue is the pro-long peak period that some have to endure, without managing their associates engagements.

headline: Long and irregular hours, no work life balance, promise of being valued but no actual weight
pros: Global Brand Name is good and public perception is that you are a hard worker who can slog for hours
cons:
Underpaid in contrast to hours worked, no actual commitment to train staff as you don't report to any one so you are viewed as "any other resource".

You are expected to perform at least 3 ranks higher by yourself based on observation (e.g Assoc 1 shd be performing at around Sr 2 or Sr 3 level and above, while Sr 1 shd be performing at M1 and above) if you want a bonus between 2-4 months (and even if you could, the opportunity to do so doesn't always come by, as the firm always staffs as many consultants possible to charge more to the client) so you don't get the chance to shine even if you had the capacity to. Bonus across is 1.4mths standard (80% of people will get this).

Unless you are in audit taking your professional papers, in consulting, training is usually self sponsored or just udemy e-learning or e-learning. No actual sponsorship for training & dev of staff.

headline: TOXIC AND DISHONEST
pros:
- Some of the projects can be good for learning
- Brand recognition
cons:
- Ridiculously low wages and bonuses for the insanely long hours required
- Partners get very high disproportionate salaries compared with lower staff levels
- Management is incredibly dishonest and they only present events/figures/KPIs in ways that serve them. For example, EY deferred promotions in the UK to 'protect the business', but it is actually a disguised cost save as they know people won't leave their jobs during Covid-19 times 
- Even though EY increased revenue significantly and achieved ALL KPIs for FY20, it decided to defer promotions blaming Covid. This indicates that EY puts money over people and disguises cost savings as 'helping the business' which is very dishonest 
- Insanely bureaucratic and secretive, even simple requests need a large number of approvals and the business is super secretive about sharing any information with employees. Way too much time is spent on admin requirements
- Power and influence is highly concentrated in the hands of Partners and lower-level employees rarely have a say on things
- There is no culture of mentorship in the business. Managers and Senior Managers only want to exploit junior members during projects and discard them afterwards when they don't need them. Therefore, there is little support for mentorship and little altruism/empathy
- Since EY competes with other companies for projects, Partners and Directors discount projects singificantly to entice clients with attractive fees. However, 9/10 projects are dramatically under-staffed which means people work insanely long stresfull hours so that Partners/Directors can say they sold a lot of work to clients. Partners/Directors know this is the case and decide to screw people who execute projects even from the beginning through the way they structure projects. 
- Partners rarely talk to juniors and they often don't answer emails if you are not senior enough 
- Hiring policies are highly immoral as they try to get overqualified people to sign contracts for positions that are lower in rank than anywhere else in the market, therefore offering them lower wages than what they are worth
- HR sides with the business 10/10 cases and there is no impartiality, therefore HR can't be relied on at all
- A significant amount of travel is often required, therefore negatively work-life balance 
- IT is very poor, makes most projects a nightmare
- Diversity at senior levels is a joke. Aprox. 90% of senior leaders are White British males
- Moving across teams and functions is a highly opaque process which is also not encouraged. Therefore, lateral career progression is highly difficult
- Highly unethical behavior around clients. Often projects set fees for people for positions that are more senior than in actuality to charge clients higher fees
- EY uses its power as a large organisation to use and dump people on an ongoing basis. Leaders don't care about people leaving, it is business as usual for them and they don't even have a problem with that. Instead, they should understand why people leave and create a nurturing environment.
- Everyone is afraid to speak up to Partners or Clients, even when they have insanely unreasonable demands. EY is a fear-based culture.

headline: Mostly a cutthroat culture and environment
pros: Training opportunities, great support from counselors. partners in advisory were all really supportive, really down to earth and seemed genuinely concerned with ensuring a positive and supportive working environment.
cons:
pay, insane hours, cutthroat culture; there is a very weird disconnect between partners (who in my experience, were all super supportive and seemed genuinely interested in your growth), and everyone else from seniors to managers to senior managers. In my time, i was thrown under the bus consistently only to be saved by really involved partners/executive level people who caught wind of what was going on and had to clear things up with the greater team. people who are "up for promotion" seem to do everything in their power to avoid any kind of criticism (and thus responsibility) and are quick to throw you under the bus to avoid a blemish on their case for promotion. Senior managers (who would become partners with a promotion) were the worse, in my experience. As a new employee, they were the least helpful and the most cutthroat during my time here. even worse, they feign interest in your development and how you're doing on your project, and then talk about you behind your back as they blame you for whatever is going wrong on the project. I experienced this on every project I was on. it was a recurring theme with every senior manager on every project. Managers werent much better, as they are also on the path to promotion to Senior Manager and have zero patience or interest in fostering a healthy working environment for anyone ranked below them. 
There should be a big concern if this next batch of senior managers up for promotion become partners - I have only positive experiences with existing partners, and current Sr. Managers could cause a significant change to company culture given the utter lack of compassion and toxic "get ahead at all costs" mentality.

headline: Sinking Ship
pros: Decent culture, generous time-off (for the time being), decent pay (not compared to competitors)
cons: Over the years, it’s been clearer and clearer that EY is a sinking ship. It’s made a lot of changes that claim to be “for your benefits” with a catch. The most recent change is the switch to “unlimited vacation”. This is really the punch in the face that made everyone angry. It’s a blatant robbery. The worst part is that the leadership made it sound “You asked, we listened” while literally no one asked for it. And they chose to do this just when people didn’t use vacation much this year and less than one year from the latest vacation policy change. EY Leadership these years is very hypocritical. Other than the vacation change, the performance review with LEAD has become very shady. You used to know if you’re rated 3/4/5, but the new LEAD system has no clear indication. It comes down to behind your back conversations. People with similar dashboards have different raises. Absolutely ridiculous. I used to be super proud of working for EY, and now this is very disappointing.

headline: Good Place to Work If You Like the Work; You'll Be Doing a Lot of It
pros:
Good benefits.

Good salary.

Lots of industries and projects to work on (get a breadth of experience).
Great people to work with, generally.

Flexible work schedules/environments (WFH is easy/allowed depending on the project, even before COVID).

Supportive/teaming work environment (not ultra-competitive/cut throat).
cons:
Lots of bureaucracy - To be expected in a large firm, I suppose.

Roll outs/communications of policy changes are done poorly

Lots of changes being made constantly to policies - For example: vacation policy has updated 2 times in 2 years.

Internal infrastructure needs updating - It's 2020, why do some EY tools only work in internal explorer?

Changing of Goal Posts - it seems like in the past year or so, the goal posts of what being good/great and setting yourself up for promotion keep changing (getting more difficult to achieve). Those changes aren't really communicated out, and it makes the review cycle a bit of a black box.

Work life balance is very tough - This is consulting; you know what you're getting into; the hours can be long (and you may not be allowed to book all those hours). If you like the work, this isn't a huge deal, but if you don't, it will be a nightmare of a job.

headline: Amazing workplace and career building opportunities
pros: EY strongly advocates to build and grow your career. It encourages you to continue learning skills that are of your interest so you can get promoted and maybe move to another project that aligns better with your skillset. It includes a lot of diversity and it makes you feel very welcome. This is a place where they truly care about you and advocate for your mental health, vacation, sick time, and personal care day. I love this company and my job and I never felt so loved by management. The healthcare is amazing and great plans as well. You have a lot of benefits as well such as gym membership reimbursement, working from home, discounts, etc. Ey is the place where I was able to find work life balance, enjoy my family, and be happy while growing my career. Everyone is so caring that I think I'm dreaming. I'm so happy to have accepted to be part of EY.
cons: long hours but that was expected from the interview.

headline: A big name on your resumé, but GET OUT asap.
pros: Office view, good hours (but you need to fight hard for this), WFH opportunities depending on the client, there's an abundance of colleauges so you're bound to make some friends, there are some genuinely good people in management, the ability to basically be on paid leave when between engagements if you keep your head down.
cons: Pay, some very very toxic people in management who can hurt your career if they single you out, performance reviews are redundant as they aren't even taken into account come promotion season, clients tend to be difficult and if you don't have good colleauges or support on an engagement you'll be very unhappy, engagement teams are picked based on friendships and politics, most engagements are absolute s*%t shows with no order or direction anyway, the "work" looks good from the outside but in reality it's quite bland, as you're learning survival and crisis-management above all.

headline: Not for techies
pros: - The team that I worked with was great.
cons:
- They hired me as a data analyst but the type of work was mostly irrelevant. Except for some projects. 
- They are very stingy with the budget for tech teams.
- The tech teams are not treated as "important" by the financial partners. 
- Their focus was analytics but they shifted their focuss to digital.
- The compensation is abysmal.
- Benefits are below average.
- Due to COVID, they took away all our accumulated leaves and did not let us encash our leaves.
- The new leave policy is terrible.

headline: Good people to work with.. generally
pros: There are a lot of people here that really care about the success of their people. However, for every one that there is, there is another that gets caught up in only focusing on the client and delivering the project no matter what the cost is to their people. Work life balance can be a focus, but is sometimes only in words and not in practice.
cons: While managing your own career has its upsides, it can be challenging for someone who is not the typical "A type personality" to be appreciated - you have to act the part and do and act in such a way that may be counter to your personality to get the higher ups to like and support your upward progression.

headline: Sets you up for success! But I also recommend going to industry after a few years

Teaches attention to detail like no other.

cons:

People believe is working harder but not smarter.
If you want to keep employees care about their interests, passion and goals.

To be fair, diversity mix is improving - but more needs to be done - they haven't cracked it yet.
cons: Too many toxic work traits are encouraged which can bring out the worst in people. Throwing people under the bus, covering their backs, presenteeism. Glad I got out back into the 'real corporate world' before the poison seeped my way.

headline:
Actuarial BPO
P&C
pros:
- work from home options
nothing else
cons:
- this is an actuarial BPO - almost running at the mercy of US team 
- Cant challenge actuarial assumptions, get into discussions etc, what we are asked to do is mostly copy-paste work from prior analysis and then all the decisions will betaken by the US actuarial person
- Learning curve will go downwards not even stagnate- eg- since the work of the offshore unit is just to do copy-paste job and make hours and not do quality job, you will be swamped by massive workload, hence no time to spend on analysis or making sense of results. 
- extremely defensive management. Even if you bring these points to management, you will be made a joke in the conversation
- management is just toooo scared of onshore guys- cant take a stand for their Indian colleagues, doesnt allow offshore guys to openly ask doubts to onshore to protect image
- No holiday- none trust me- between OCTOBER to March
except in Christmas when onshore guys take leave
but that can also get cancelled if your onshore manager dumps work for u while she/he is away
in short- no cultural diversity- no leave on diwali, holi , weddings - not even 2 days. Plus no study leave during this time. That means your April exam is nothing but a wasted effort 
while US ppl can take leaves for 1-2 weeks for christmas, thanksgiving and CASACT exams even during busy season
- no control over your career- so lets say you have expertise in AXIS they might put you for prophet bcz they just want someone to produce hours and not value someones skills or expertise

headline: Not the best of the Big 4
pros:
- Exposure to different industries
- Good stepping stone to launch your career
- Fun colleagues
- Challenging work
cons:
- Poor compensation. For FY2020, even though our department achieved our budget, there was reduction in increment and bonuses, with management giving excuses of 'Covid-19'. Even so, all I have seen is more projects coming in, so this is really unfair.
- Ridiculous bonus payment schedule. Our financial year starts from 1 July to 30 June. However, our bonus is only given on December (60%), and then the following year March (40%). Which is ridiculous.
- Poor work life balance. You are expected to work when on leave. There is no respect on your personal life outside of working hours
- Poor benefits. Any rank below manager, you won't be getting dental, optical and gym benefits. The other big 4 offers this kind of benefit to all ranks.
- No clear communication between management and staffs. Management do not actively communicate what's going on with the business. When pitching for new jobs, management do not actively engage staffs or ask staffs for opinion/feedback. Even during staff planning, management do not ask for staffs opinion/feedback

headline: Good place to have steep learning curve
pros: Good salary and exposure to industries
cons: No work-life balance, poor work from home arrangement

headline: Company Overview
pros: Place where we can work on different Technologies, dont need to bind with single path. company itself offers immense opportunities to work for clients on different projects.
cons: Have to manage both Client and Parent company fundamentals. If we are habituated its better.

headline: Good company culture
pros: People are genuinely willing to support you
cons: As the firm is based on project , you can't really choose a project you are truly interested in when it comes to staffing. You will be assigned based on client needs within your own practice. For example, tech risk has a strong needs in auditing project so the chance of you getting staffed on an auditing project is a lot higher than that of a advisory project.

headline: Audit
pros: The people of my rank who I started with or have come from overseas are some of my best friends, and will support me through anything.
cons: Audit busy season is never ending, with continue late nights to meet internal deadlines in the non-busy season period, the work life balance no non-existent. Feedback from management is negative to the point where you do know why they have booked you on their jobs, and give very little positive encouragement or thanks. Management also talk about supporting people to move internally if they are no longer happy in division, but when you actually try, they try to block by delaying your move or feeling like its hampering your current position.

headline: Big4 is the place to start

- Biggest clients to work for.
- Strong towards diversity, wellbeing of employees, working from home.

cons:

headline: Awful Work Environment - Good Name for CV - Adelaide Street Office
pros:
-Payday drinks on the last Friday of every month, social committee were amazing
-Good Christmas parties
-Good name to have on your CV
-Modern offices
-Some travel if that's what you want
-Casual dress
-Good training opportunities if you know where to look
cons:
-Terrible management, 'rules for thee but not for me' type, bullying and harassment went ignored by managers as they were friends
-Promotions more dependent on if the managers liked you the most rather than your performance
-Blatant office politics and favoritism towards some members of staff by management
-The Adelaide office is an offshore delivery centre, meaning all work that the main UK business doesn't want to do is sent here, can be extremely tedious and monotonous with very little skill development
-Managers will bully people out and encourage them to leave, never experienced something so unprofessional in my entire life
-The firm claims to be 'mental health champions' and that you can always reach out, the reality is management couldn't care less
-Extremely low pay. By far the lowest in Belfast for similar work, multiple offers were turned down by candidates due to this, would recommend checking the salaries section in glassdoor for EY Belfast
-Management couldn't care less about alarming retention rate, 15 people left in 8 months out of a team of around 40 yet don't take action or address it 
-Flexi-working is advertised and was mentioned at interview several years ago but some managers would not let you work from home or operate on a more flexible schedule under any circumstances, this has now changed to some flexi-working being available after working there for 6 months (though obviously this has changed during covid-19)
-Some managers are absolutely useless and are very unorganized and very unprofessional
-Office can be quite clique

In short, EY Adelaide Belfast Office should be avoided, or left as quickly as possible

headline: Classic Graduate Trap
pros: Immediate work with significant global clients.
cons:
Terrible pay (I was making more when I worked retail). They made me a verbal offer for a position without mention of remuneration. I (foolishly) accepted as I was excited to work at a large firm. I'll not make that mistake again.
 It quickly becomes apparent that everything is running sub-par as a corporate cost cutting measure. I had to get written approval from an equity partner to have access to colour printing.
I was uncomfortable with the sexual and demeaning language used by a partner. Was told 'they're an Oceanic leader and that's that.'

headline: Depends on the team
pros: You have the opportunity to work with large, public companies. You are surrounded by intelligent people that encourage innovation, but I have never felt like I need to “compete” against coworkers. My coworkers are what keep me at EY - I work on some great engagements with solid people, all the way from staff to partner. My managers care about supporting my personal goals, and are great mentors. The pay is fair, though... [see cons]
cons:
You will work. A lot. If you don’t enjoy what you do, you can’t make it. I don’t have a family, but I could see how it would be difficult to juggle family life with the work schedule. I was prepared for a crazy busy season, working 24/7 for 2 months... but busy season ends up bleeding into the rest of the year, depending on your engagements.

Also... it seems like a lot of the internal HR sites are really clunky, and some of the tech we use seems prehistoric.

headline: Strategy & Transaction
pros: You get to interact with client very quickly
cons:
EY = CHAOS. Complete Chaos
-Extremely high internal competition among teams for projects (infact there is a system akin to fastest finger first for pursuing proposals or bids, because multiple partners are doing the same thing in same territory)
-I have worked with other big-4 consulting firms, and I am sure that EY is worst
-Partners and Senior Partners are EXTREMELY Greedy. (Leech, is the internal lingo). They just wanna make quick bucks and vanish.
-Employees pay for Out of Pocket Expense (OPEs) on Projects from their salaries. Directors/Partners will often reject your expense claims, citing weird/baseless reasons.
-Seniors lack knowledge, lack vision, and completely lack sector understanding 
-Negotiate extremely well before joining. Dont worry, EY will hire you; because they need smart and hardworking people; You just need not put your foot down.
- Money is the only language here. Don't fall for caring words. Once you join; they will make sure that there is no increment for atleast a couple of years.
-Firm does not care about clients (forget employees). Its only Money.. Whether the project is fruitful for client, or whether the team is able to deliver; doesn't matter
-HR or employee policies are non-existent. 
-On top of everything, to remove transparency - buggers have eliminated rating system... so, however well you perform; you wont get any rating.. (seems good, but if you think about it - it's actually detrimental for high-performing people)
-While at EY, you will get a feel of working in a typical marwadi/baniya shop ; owner gets rich++ and employees get peanuts

headline: EY Review
pros: Massive focus on learning and development of employees. Standard process, Decent Salary. Health benefits are not great but passable. Very stable and won't fire unless you break compliance.
cons: EY is a partner based org. It is not a connected MNC. Everyone amd everything is partner focused. Network and connections are more impt than client delivery. If you can't develop business you will not grow. Senior people have a hell lot of ego amd attitude. It has booth good and bad.. depends which team you land up to.

headline: Senior Consultant review
pros: Learning ability, Career development and Annual promotions
cons: Low salary and Work-life balance

headline: Great brand / tough environment

headline: Grass is greener elsewhere
pros: Not much, other than the fact that you train up on your technical skills and exposure to a variety of industries and companies. In addition, many MNCs do look for Big 4 candidates especially in the Finance role.
cons:
- low pay at associate to senior level
- OT culture (very common in Big 4, I know even before I joined but you really see emails flying around at 2/3/4am)
- to add on to OT culture, my first year I worked from 9am to 5am, grab home wash up, rest 2h and came back to work, REPEAT X5-6 TIMES A WEEK)
- toxic culture (seniors and managers are not appreciative of your work, they take the extra effort and work you put in for granted)
- adding on to toxic culture: personal experience with toxic seniors that sent you extremely long emails just to criticise you and put you down, the kind where you go into office in the morning with a happy mood and when you see the email from senior, your whole day is ruined
- my own experience with line manager: my LM has never talked to me, even for feedback sessions, except for my last day in EY. To be very honest, a good manager is important in your first few years of career

headline: Big Company with lots of different teams/departments - some better than others
pros: The company has name recognition and pays pretty fairly for entry level jobs. I felt a lot of growth in a business setting and was offered lots of opportunities to get in front of clients.
cons: I was in the IT audit practice and it was monotonous. Lots of time in spreadsheets, talking to elderly government IT department heads, and there was a 45 hour a week minimum for billable hours. The company wants to take as much of your time as they can. If you drink the kool aid then great, but for most its draining.

headline: Awesome company, little bit time management issue
pros: Awesome is every aspect except one.
cons: That one reason for cons is the users/clients. They don't understand technology and everyone is in hurry, if they give a task in morning by evening they need it, software development is not done that way, also they don't understand how to give requirements. Everyday and every week requirements changes, whenever it goes in uat , they come with bugs or issues and you notice it is not a bug, it is a new requirement. Your one project doesn't end and another starts. And nothing ends. Never ends. You may feel one or two week it is ended now but again CRs will Co due to leadership or client was some change.

headline: Kolkata IDT team worst experience ever
pros: Kolkata IDT team is worst
cons: Partner is a ringmaster and all the directors and managers follow his orders like a joker. There is no respect to employees below manager who are treated like bonded labor. Many employees have left over last few months. I don't know what is their focus - taking personal revenge with employees or being professional and put all the energy to grow business.

headline: Excellent Exposure, No Work Life Balance
pros:
- Excellent industry exposure.
- For those live-to-work person and workaholic. 24 hours working? 10000% recommended.
- Great exposure to work in cross-country projects
- Great tools, almost unlimited Udemy (free)
- Perform = Guaranteed Annual Promotion (for manager below, From Associate to Senior Associate)
cons:
- Overtime money / compensation always delayed 2-3 months, because your charge code is usually generated during or even after the projects.
- No standardized coaching, usually you will be deployed directly into projects and help the ongoing ones before proper basic knowledge first. Learn it by doing. (Usually the training is late after some months of your employment date, because they have certain timings for the training)
- Work over the weekends in hectic Projects, including daily overtime (11-14 Hours per day)
- Really high turn over. Sometimes you can see 3-4 People resign every week in your email, or even in a day.
- Old Office

headline: grotesquely inhumane
pros: seems impressive to your aunts and uncles
cons: Have you heard of indentured servitude? it's when europeans couldn't pay for their voyage to America. So American landlords "paid" for their voyage to America in return for the European to work 4-6 years of manual labour on the farm. If the European wanted to up and leave, he would have to pay his debt of the voyage and/or be prosecuted/trialled for running away. Did the servant get paid overtime or in leu hours? No. Was the servant stuck for 3 years (until CPA hours incurred) against literal debt to EY? Yes. >>Terrible pay, 90 hour work week, feel like you are never doing enough, and inherently boring work.

headline: FSO FAAS

cons: EY's emphasis on "one EY" means that we get pulled into Advisory projects which tend to be mundane and never ending. Working in FAAS can be a roll of the dice in that if you get staffed on a crappy ADV job, you may lose 6 months doing data entry.

headline: Place where you can develop your leadership and skills
pros:
1. One of the best leading public accountant in the world, there's a pride in doing your job.
2. Clear career patch, give your best, individually and as a team
3. Growing responsibility as your career level grows, ensuring that you are in the right track.
4. Fellow professionals from various backgrounds ensuring you to always motivated with your life and career goals.
5. Various clients with multiple industries, allowing you to get exposure on whatever fields you want to focus on
6. Nurturing your durability through tough busy season, and various clients backgrounds
cons:
1. Administration for transport and overtime is manual - hard copy
2. Long working hours are fine, the difficulty is when you have to face more than 3 clients, with same deadline, promising of lack of sleep and rest, particularly during the weekdays.
3. unpredictable situation such as immediate client engagements, although it could be challenging in a fun way, imagine facing tight deadline, and you'll have to face another client that you did not anticipate.

headline: Stereotypical big 4 company, with a slight lean toward employee satisfaction
pros:
- Decent money
- Good opportunities if you're a business major and love networking
- Senior Partners/Principals do seem to listen a bit, but most everyone in the middle is failing upwards (good talent leaves)
- Way better peers than any of the other big 4. Deloitte is snotty, PwC employees are overworked and arrogant, and KPMG is well...oft forgotten.
cons:
- Unable to hire any good tech talent as it is all elsewhere working fewer hours for better total comp
- Acquisition team is out of touch and tone deaf
-  Company as a whole is stuck in the past, saying one thing, and doing another, and when they try to catch up to the future they do so only because it benefits their bottom line (see also their "unlimited" vacation policy)
- Senior Managers / Partners on projects are often inflexible and use overworking their project staff as a means to save themselves on margins, even though company policy states you must log all your hours you are almost always told to just log a flat number.
- Processes are out of control in scale and scope. Get ready to submit lots of TPS reports, especially as you move up.

headline: "The nature of the industry"
pros: Great benefits - apparently there's a 5 word minimum for pros.
cons:
If on the West Coast, the staff and senior pay is well below average, since salaries are standardized nationally (HR has never provided any material justification for this decision).
Depending on the project you're on, both your physical and mental health may be put in jeopardy unless you absolutely love the work you do. The ones who stay are the ones who live to work (and specifically this kind of work), rather than work to live. 
The marketing doesn't align with what actually happens. HR and Staffing Managers will say to speak up in case you're feeling overwhelmed, but when you do, you're met with the response indicated in this review's title. If it's a repeat project, you're forced to work on every iteration, no matter how much you speak up, since they think the carryover knowledge will help them save on budget.
It truly depends on the individuals you work with, so you're forced to hunt down people with reasonable work expectations (40-45 hours, 50-55 during busy season), but unfortunately, there aren't many here.
Due to competition among the Big 4, leadership will always take the "bottom of the barrel" engagements, that involve unreasonable client expectations for a heavily discounted fee. This causes individuals to not charge full hours, take shortcuts in their work, work days at a time with little to no sleep, thereby resulting in poor engagement quality overall.

headline: Great only if you enjoy being a salesperson
pros: Great colleagues; a variety of project opportunities
cons: you won't learn many advanced techniques as an actuary. This job, especially as you move up, is all about selling chargeable hours. There are plenty of consultants at this company don't know technical aspects of the projects they work on, but they keep moving up because they are good at "selling". This is not necessarily a bad thing. It's not good for me because I don't enjoy it if that's all a job is about.

headline: One of the worst company for ServiceNow Developers - Never Join!!!!
pros: Nothing that I found out except for a few year end parties.
cons:
1. No Onsite
2. You get WFH but managers remind u that its a privilege and not an entitlement
3. For every WFH u have to inform managers on why u want to take WFH
4. Heavy Politics
5. In order to grow u have to be a bootlicker
6. They don't have good ServiceNow projects 
7. Most of the ServiceNow projects are internal
8. The only way to change the project is by leaving the company
9. Managers make u a fool during hiring
10. Manager/s and Senior Manager/s are the most cunning duo of the company, they will lure u into joining the company by saying sweet words but once u join u will realize that its a bigger scam than Scam 1992
11. Bad HR support.
12. Worst is managers have the full authority to decide on your future, if u dnt lick their boots u will be just another guy.
13. No proper Policy
14. Medical insurance is worst
15. 90 days notice period if u are below Senior Consultant -2 designation
16. Counsellors (Reporting Managers) are the puppet of managers, no one will fight for you even if u are deserving.
17. You cant change your counsellor even if u want.
18. Overall don't go with the outlook of the company coz this ServiceNow Team contains Scammers.

Seniors keep leaving during peak, year 1s left to fend for themselves. 
Year 2s assigned to help, but they're from mid-tier firms and also struggle to be leaders. 
Managers don't care about under staffing, blame the Y1 audit assistants if audits are not completed on time. 
Politics all around, and between managers. Need to play your cards right and win favour of most managers, so your life and reviews are better.

headline: EY is only selling brand but inside purely a street culture, no professional s
pros: Only Brand. The only outing on a yearly basis
cons:
Below are the details one should consider before joining the company.

1) In India Banglore, they have only limited clients and they usually have a Partner model way of working. If you got the mail id as in.ey.con, I prefer to go to Galli organization rather than this. If they have a project then only consider people. 
2) If you are out of the project they will demotivate you till you left the company. 
3) You recruit for one skill set and you need to act as a rocket scientist.
4) Especially they look money nothing more than that. 
5) NO Job security, better to go for Level 3 rather than this culture.
6) No policy noting going to work, as I am a permanent employee though they simply act as they want.
7) In Banglore they had 90% attrition on every year.

headline: As a big4 firm, it’s a great brand name and exposure ; but that’s where it ends.
pros: Brand name, exposure to sectors and clients; networked organisation; systems and processes
cons:
- bureaucratic procedures 
- teams don’t collaborate within the same practice 
- very poorly paid, overworked employees in spite of good revenues 
- almost a bonded labour culture, where anyone getting opportunity outside of the firm is harassed while leaving with vendetta for leaving this bondage 
- lack of technical and innovative solutions to work upon, just run of the mill projects 
- lack of knowledge being made up for with jargons and flashy ppts
- short term, top line focused leadership with focus on revenues. Not in talent, not on client delight either. In fact, once projects are won, nobody cares about deliverables and the project is left to the junior most employees who have no experience, receive no guidance and no training in subject matter 
- typical working day 9.30am to 12midnight; 3/4 weekends working too 
- lacks transparency towards employees 
-  very similar to all big4/ BBM firm culture, some are just worse than others

headline: Great for exposure, poor for work-life balance
pros: The level of exposure is undeniable as you'll have various opportunities to work with some of the biggest clients as well as alongside international peers. Occasional perks are nice i.e. vouchers and free food on your birthday, department activities but this is very much limited to the division you are in. You are also given the ability to attend beneficial trainings for free like Power BI and other MFRS/IFRS trainings in-house. Flexible working arrangements and newly introduced flexi-leave and "free" MC days. Ability to dress casually every day if stationed at the office.
cons: The department's structure is very lean and so the expectations to pull double duty is very frequent. Workload is intense especially given its high unpredictability. Working overtime every day throughout a project is also expected but being able to fully claim this ends up being a tiring process of running this by a manager who may not agree with it to meet the budget constraints. Managers are promoted to that level based on narrow criteria and are not further assessed based on their abilities to connect and support staff's growth and development but this is also likely due to the frequent rotation of projects and team members. Bonus payout system is in tranches (60:40).

headline: Worst Ever Company - EY LLP
pros: No pros in this company
cons:
-Verbally they will say to give the buyout and joining bonus but after sending the offer letter they will just say that they need to take approvals and it will take time.
- Management changes the policies like clothes . Policy differ from person to person . Manager give threats . Management doesn't even bother to reply for the query asked. 
- No Leave Encashment , Leave policy changed 
- HR directly doesn't talk to the employee they involve manager into this and whatever manager says HR says the same thing. 
- They give roles irrespective of the skills . I have seen developers doing excel work and testing  in one of their Dell EMC project.
- No hikes ,very less bonus , bonus percent not mention on offer letter as they say Big four company doesn't do that.
- Worst compensation structure 
- They will ask you to join early and will say they will give buyout pay don't believe them and they will hire you in 10 days but will keep their notice period for 90 days.
- No leave policies mentioned on offer letter . There offer letter is of 2 pages only

headline: Brutal work hours and expectations - No real AI/ quant opportunities for career growth
pros: Admin / HR teams are helpful and do their job. Fitness reimbursement is encouraging. Free access to Udemy.
cons:
- Deep Learning / Quant / all fancy stuff is just on slides - Not in reality. The worst part is you will have to do most of these creative powerpoint decks

The canadian team is no where comparable to EY US / EY UK in terms of quality of Quant / FS relevant opportunities. In my years of experience here, I witnessed no good projects in the area of Quant space (such as Front-office pricing models (Heston process, local vol based), Market Risk (VaR/CVA etc) model development / validation). EY US/UK are the ideal places for quant, AI and FinTech implementation work.

 - The projects they do are mostly AML Transaction Monitoring (why should one study Stochastic calculus for ending up working on outdated rules-based modeling stuff?) , Credit risk (uncountable hours of Internal audit), DVC (internal auditing mostly)

- One of the leaders said during many occasions that 60 hours/week is a normal expectation

- You will most likely work on something else (on internal/decks/other client) besides your FULL-TIME work hours at a different client during after-hours in evenings

headline: False promises and general backstabbing culture
pros: Good name on your vita
cons: The culture in the Zurich office is toxic, I would really recommend not to work there. Management generally promises tasks and jobs that they can not offer, sometimes even based on the wrong subject understanding (especially in data science). I have seen numerous occasions where junior staff members have been treated with upmost disrespect and exploited to serve the career of managers or partners and left after 2-3 years as soon as they realized they would never get the jobs or tasks they were promised.

headline: More work, more learning, more time, less pay
pros:
Coworkers are young, open minded, supportive, and helpful
Opportunities are available for growth and lateral movement (...if you ever have time to take adv of them) 
Good level of responsibility for the years of experience you have
Have some flexibility in terms of being able to work from home or working diff hours as long as you deliver (team dependent) 
Have independence and ownership in the work you're doing
Most managers are approachable
cons:
Hours are consistently long throughout the year
Pay is minimal given hours worked 
Consistently short-staffed and therefore you get more work and you're usually expected to perform duties that is above your pay grade (i.e. "acting senior")
No/minimal reward for top performers
Burning out is common - top talent/mentors are quitting

headline: Say no to Ernst, and young
pros: Their is nothing good about this company other than a few good clients they got because of hard working people
cons:
Despite your long/short duration of work, be is working late night and weekend and even holiday. They will make it hell when you say that you are leaving the company just to save their billing.
No learning no better opportunity.
They don't follow what they mention in their own offer letter.
HRs are just puppet of 1or2 Ppl. 
They are so inhuman, even if you say you will die if you will work here. They will make you die. 
Such companies make us realise that peace of mind is always better than money. 
With many associates situation came, they Donot provide proper and timely resignation exceptance as well as LWD. There comes situation that if you have a good opportunity then they will make sure you are going to loose it. 
The manager never responds back for LWD over mail as official communication. Many times you may get response from HR on his behalf. He was not aware of his own duties. 😂

headline: Great D&I culture
pros: EY is a great company if you’re client serving (bringing in money). They’re excellent for diversity and inclusiveness, family focused, flexible work arrangements and promoting from within.
cons: They don’t value their support staff enough to retain them through salary increases. They offer voluntary retirement offers to (average age) 50+ and have eluded to involuntary retirement offers occurring in the (not so distant) future.

headline: I wish the local management team would treat us better
pros: I had the most excellent team at EY. Everyone is agile, smart, and supportive of each other. We learned, thrived, and succeeded together. I would never forget them.
cons: The local management team does not provide us enough support, the global team does. They don't want to hire more people for the team, even after knowing how big our struggles were. It was horrible. We didn't have a supervisor, manager, or director that could support us and protect the team from partners. They were not listening to any of our concerns at all.

headline: Huge Firm
pros: Reputable reputation. Offers training. Big network. Opportunity to take up work above your rank.
cons: Because it’s such a huge firm it very easy to get lost and feel like a number. As a staff, you’re bounced around like a hot potato filling in big or small needs as they come up. So sometimes staff are stuck doing small tedious items and never really seeing the start and end of projects. However, if you’re a good performer teams look to keep you and may roll you over to all their other projects. Which is great, if you like the team and work. BUT if you don’t and want to try new things, it’s very very hard to switch. Also, good work is rewarded with more work.

headline: Good place to work (depending on team members and project)
pros:
+ They have WFH, and no strict policy to check working schedule.
+ Is one of the Big Four companies, so it add some shine to your CV.
+ Decent IT equipment provided; you can get a new working laptop if you're lucky.
+ Good place to learn things on the pace, as you'll have enough time bandwith.
cons:
- There are some corrupt colleagues arranging benefits for their own or their direct managers (family relationships or friendship)
- Many projects are a total nightmare in terms of disorden.
- Not clear career path: many marketing emails publishing it, not many opportunities around.
- HR/Ethics peers are just a nice adornment; they are not there when needed.

cons: INSANE long hours. Team would work till 2-3 am daily during busy season and till 8-9 pm on a regular basis. People would work on weekends and take PTO to catch up on work if needed. headline: Good start for freshers - but more cons than pros
pros:
1. Good working exposure - You will be working for best-in-industry companies
2. Complete process understanding - We will be reviewing the end-to-end processes of the complany
cons:
1. No work-life balance - Leave your life at the door before entering EY or this job profile. This is can be very frustrating
2. Toxic work culture - work culture is very bad. Completely depends on the team you work though
3. Less HR intervention - HR does not react or act to find out the welfare or mental wellness of the employees
4. Impossible expectations in a short time: Expecting to work on more than one client is okay but to work without any support from senior is torture
5. Narrow scope: Scope of any fresher shall be limited only to internal audit

headline: Great people, clunky/inefficient internal processes

cons: Performance review process is geared specifically towards client serving individuals, but is used for internal (non-client facing) roles as well. The result is a vague, very subjective process with little transparency for internal employees.

headline: Not worth the headache! For real..... RUN
pros: you can put ey on your resume... that's about it
cons:
So many to list, here are some of the most obvious:
- The work life balance even in SDC is non-exsistent. 
- You get treated like another number. 
- They claim they're family oriented but they aren't you'll find yourself working 60 hour weeks, holidays, and getting pushback when you need a day off. 
- Very little flexibility. 
- Prepared to be micromanaged like you've never been before. To the point where they will literally ask you to like a message to show you've read and understand (messages as simple as please fill out your timesheets or projected deadlines months out.
- Not a team job however you will be expected to be a team - meaning you can't leave unless the slackers on the rest of the team finish their tasks.

headline: Blatant Favouritism, Just a Number
pros: I met lots of great people in my 4.5 years in EY. The people were the best part.
cons:
The is a blatant favouritism in EY for certain people. Especially in consulting. I witnessed first hand people getting special treatment and people getting promotions just because of favouritism and not based on their work alone.

They express that they care about you but I eventually came to see I was just a number 

I’m leaving after 4.5 years, I barely got so much as an email thanking me for my time and effort. The partners were aware I was leaving and never reached out to me. On my last day I received no well wishes or anything of the sort. It was a very upsetting experience and I felt like I wasted my time and effort in this company for so long. I am happy now in my new company and I can see even more clearly how badly EY treat people who are not on their radar as ‘favourites’

- management is legitimately terrible, have tricked employees into working hard for overtime, to later tell them they do not qualify (management has actually checked in with employees not working on the weekend as they are thought to have "capacity")
- terrible overall workplace, not many employees are legitimately happy
- uses the promise of "work - life balance" to pay less, however they are no better than any other firm in that regard

I could go on forever but I'd rather not beat a dead horse here, if you have ABSOLUTELY NO other choice, its a passable experience however I would not recommend this firm to anyone.

headline: EY London
pros: 1. exposure to different industries 2. will have many coworkers that are the same/similar age as you 3. international secondment opportunities (to high performers)
cons:
1. Salary is not competitive 2. Work life balance is really team based - depends on the partners/managers 3. fees charged to client are low therefore budget is limited, which then result in understaff in teams (and overworked employees) 4. promotion to manager is not clear or fair. It seems like they purposely fail everyone who takes the exam so that they will stay for at least another year to complete their remediation and hope to get promoted. Normally there are 60-80 people who will take the manager assessment and the most recent exam had 0% passing rate. Even if an individual have positive feedback from their managers, they are not allowed to be promoted if they fail the exam. The exam is not a good measurement or reflective of what a manager will do, and the marking scheme is not clear. The company does not return the exam to the individuals, nor do they provide the answer key or marking scheme. 
5. HR makes really simple but severe mistakes, such as incorrectly sending promotion notice to individuals then retracting them and clawing back the additional salary in the next month, booked hotel with incorrect dates for new employees arriving in UK. It doesn't seem like anyone can hold them accountable for their mistakes. No reasons or investigation are given.
