headline: Horrible experience, As good as committing su!c!de.
pros:
1)Its a Big four company.

2)Its giving free covid vaccine for all employees in specific locations(Mayanagri, Garden city).

3)Udemy business account to upskill(though they don't consider your skills while tagging to projects).
cons:
1)Work culture is not at all employee friendly, senior management doesn't consider employee requests. there is lot of communication gap. even after a year don't know where to go for some of queries(No HR, partners are gods)

2)IMPORTANT: If you join under EY India LLP, you will be working as a contract employee for other companies that too with 2 to 3 decades old technology irrespective of the tech you interviewed for.(i wish it was communicated b4 hand)

3)I was interviewed on Latest technologies but i was assigned with 2 decades old tech which i don't have any knowledge on.

4)You would be working from client locations, EY doesn't contact you either, thus no base for increment/bonus. It will be peanuts.

5)Releases are planned on weekends and you are expected to be working without comp off or extra pay as opposed to permanent employees.
You have to be working late nights and weekends and even holidays(without leaves). They will make it like that just to save their billing.(typical contract job)

6)Internet bills are not reimbursed by company even in covid time. Even for other reimbursements process is not smooth.

7)So overall they set a Gold Standard of Exploitation.

This point does not sound like much because you might not be able to really quantify or picture what it is like, but trust me, if you just want to be a better version of yourself, this is a good place to start.
cons: Same same things - long work hours, I think we should be paid a bit more for what we do. Sometimes management is all about numbers and there can be a disconnect when they forget the people element that people constitute and contribute to those numbers.

headline: No work-life balance ; just another cog in the wheel

cons:

- Shortage of resources b/c EY significantly over-works their people.
- Leadership and communication need improvement.

headline: Good place for your career for some people
pros: Good learning opportunities and client exposure, work with some amazing people
cons:
Lots of nepotism, if you are not part of the clique then you may struggle with getting opportunities. Some of the Management team (Senior Manager and above) only want to know you if you make a project a success (or not even interested in getting to know you) and lack authenticity.
For a large organisation, D&I in some teams are poor especially at the leadership level and some of the initiatives are sometimes not well thought out
Lack of recognition and performance review process needs significant improvement to add value

headline: Ride you like a rented mule

headline: Don't Do it.
pros: If you are willing to sacrifice your relationships and your mental health, you can make a lot of money
cons: Long hours, unnecessary travel, heavy workloads, unfair production expectations. You're just a number in a very large company. They tout often that they are listed as a top employer, but those are industry publications. You will work very hard and a very expensive rate to make money for someone 2-4 levels above you who had to do the same a few years back. You'll get paid a fraction of what they do for doing all their work for them. They don't promote women and there are a lot of issues/incidents that are swept under the rug. Don't expect compassion, good training, or good pay.

headline: Competitive culture.
pros: KPMG tries very hard to give its employees good benefits, like on site massages and free flu shots. Work is challenging and you will learn alot in a short period of time. Very supportive of its junior staff to achieve CA certification giving in house training and study leave. A good and clear career path if you are ambitious. Very culturally respective office environment - for example if you don't feel like alcohol, you aren't pushed into drinking it.
cons: High volume of work can mean long nights. Culture is a hit and miss, and highly depends on your team. Overall very competitive between departments/partners/even staff. Compensation can be on a lower side and less transparent than other Big4. I guess it depends on how well you can negotiate your salary.

headline: Terrible place
pros: The onboarding experience was great, despite the COVID-19 situation.
cons:
I arrived on a project where it was clear it was going to fail. I pointed out that there was no way we were going to make the deadline from day 1. The worst programming practices had been used for the project, and my co-workers barely seemed to have sufficient knowledge regarding the programming languages and frameworks used. The team lead often got offline at 3 PM and never gave clear instructions for the team. The project manager and other consultants left right before the project was about to blow up. The moment I finished the last bug in the backlog, I got a call from HR to say I was fired for bad performance.

I started applying for jobs, I was interviewed by companies that had worked on that specific project, they told me the environment was very political and they were aware the KPMG software engineering team was making bad decisions all the time. I was told I was the victim of a political fallout. I asked HR for an audit on the project which never happened. HR doesn't care whether you're actually performing good or bad. If someone wants you out you're gone, even if they're the ones at fault.

It couldn't get worse than this, KPMG tried to withhold all my salary until I gave them back the laptop and iPhone. But I was on vacation so I couldn't. I would have to wait almost 2-3 months for my salary to arrive. When I pointed out the article in the Luxembourg labor law, they suddenly complied.

After that they were still refusing to issue me my certificates necessary to apply for unemployment benefits.

After doing interviews for EY, Deloitte and PwC, KPMG is clearly behind its competitors in Luxembourg.

Don't lie about benefits, staff is not eligible for health insurance first 2 years of employment, and they're not eligible for pension plans the first 8 years of employment, yet it's marketed as if you're getting it from day 1. You'll also get a worn out iPhone as a 'benefit' as well as a company laptop you cannot use for personal use, which was also listed as a benefit.

Don't move to Luxembourg for KPMG if you value your career. I looked for work after being fired for 1 month and a half without success. I moved back abroad to a country where I don't speak the native language and found another job from my first interview.

headline: Fragmented culture: Experience depends on working with the right Partner (KPMG Strategy)
pros:
- Good learning environment
- Smart peers
- Good brand
cons:
- Work-life balance 
- Regular weekend work
- Short term revenues prioritised over getting the right work (limited "pure" Strategy work found here)
- Competitive culture that is systemic from the top: everyone out for themselves attitude
- High-pressure environment
- Due to no specialisation occurring until an individual becomes an Engagement Manager, Partners do not think about having sustainable working relationships with Managers, Senior Consultants and Consultants. This leads to Partners pushing consultants to the limit and a high burn out rate. This has led to high churn.

headline: Don't expect to be their priority
pros:
You'll learn a lot of technical aspects of the job.
You'll learn how to deal with work under pressure.
Prestige because it's a Big Four firm.
You'll get leadership opportunities.
cons:
Your health and well-being is not a priority. They aren't willing to make the tough decisions to give their employees a decent working environment.

You will work crazy hours for most of the year. It is not an exaggeration to say that going home while the sun is still up will be a nice surprise sometimes.

You will be underpaid. Not in comparison to what other audit firms pay (because they all underpay), but in comparison to people who do their articles outside of public practice. And no, the Big Four prestige doesn't make up for it.

headline: Loads to improve on if Management acknowledges it
pros:
Very dependent on your department, I was fortunate to work with a good team.

- Supportive team and flat hierarchy
- Opportunities are present for junior staff
- Good mentorship (Subjective)
- Engagements can be interesting
- Young, Vibrant workforce
cons:
- One of the least competitive salary packages in the market especially if you are a junior staff
- Performance management not taken seriously by management, every year most employees get a sweeping rating on the pretext that the economy isn't doing well
- Bad management communications (handling of the Covid19 crisis is really poor when it comes to B&I)
- Lack of higher management direction for the company
- Non-empathetic higher management

headline: KPMG is a good place to start a career
pros:
Good exposure
Confidence builder: The nature of work I did at the firm has helped me to build my confidence. I used to be shy and timid, with low self esteem but due to the types of situations I functioned in successfully at the firm, I was able to develop my confidence level.
Commitment to excellence: The firm is committed to excellence in the work that we do and this is reflected in all aspects of work.
Good salary
cons:
1. There is sometimes too much reliance on HIPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion). Hence, the direction of work is geared towards the boss' interest and not necessarily the best output from the team.
2. The firm works people too hard and sometimes there is no respect for people's personal lives. This mostly reflects in the taboo attitude towards people going on vacation. It's as if going on vacation is rubbing the firm instead of taking an earned break from the stress of work.

headline: Best Career Starter
pros: Best place to start your career in accounting or auditing. You will get exposure to all levels of the accounting and finance departments from CFO to staff accountants over time, in addition to working with cross functional departments both internally and at clients. Exposed to mostly CPAs as colleagues (for the most part all relatively smart individuals). Extraordinary amount of resources (trainings, technical accountants, etc.) that you won't find in private accounting. Opportunities for great, long lasting mentors.
cons: Compensation is not in line with market value for skill level you develop over time (especially considering amount of hours worked) until you make Partner and/or are in it for the long term. Expected to work weekends. Not much work/life balance. Everlasting and never ending increases in scrutiny from regulators resulting in more work for same pay.

headline: Highly Glorified Industry - Not for All
pros:
1. Peers from best colleges
2. Brand Value - your cv will glitter after spending time in a Big 4
3. Huge clientele
cons:
1. Over- Glorified industry, real work is very mainstream. at times you feel overqualified for the job
2. When the work is so mainstream, supervisors/guides/managers usually focus more on subjective stuff like your colouring skills in presentations to point out how badly you have done your work and it was them who saved the day by reviewing your work
3. Tough competition between partners and their teams makes seeking help from peers difficult - Every leader wants to receive help from other teams but don't wish to offer any in return
4. Environment is very toxic if you are susceptible to negativity. you really need to be thick skinned and know the art of filtering whats been told to you if u want to make a career here

headline: Working environment
pros:
KPMG as part of their work culture conducts thorough and in depth analysis during audit process for its clients. 
You almost know everybody in your audit department group. Everyone is friendly there and as such there is no negativity with regards to working with your peers.
cons:
Working late nights is the norm here. If you are not working beyond 8pm that means you are not working seriously.
One of the major default in their working is that audit staff has IT admin passwords which they use to change time and date to allow audit documentation beyond deadlines. I haven't encountered any such instance but anyone can heavily misuse the password to bring down the entire KPMG network with it. Everyone in the audit from associate/ article trainee to the partner knows about sharing of IT admin password and they don't care

There is NO clean desk policy. They have a policy but just in papers. You can see audit and tax files lying all around office. If one wants to intentionally seek out any information regarding public companies, it is quite easy, just grab any file in the office lying around and 4 out of 10 times you may come across information about a public company. And there are no cameras to see who is looking for the information. If you are worried about being caught by other co-workers then just come to office on a Sunday of late night after 12am.
Apart from potential fraud opportunities, not following the clean desk policy makes the KPMG office seem like a govt. office and just reduces the quality of work environment. You just sometimes don't feel like working there.

cons:

headline: Run far away from this place
pros: Name recognition, WFH stipend, 401k match, Travel opportunities
cons: Horrible insurance - my new company's insurance is 1/5th the cost with 5x the coverage. Relocating is nearly impossible. Rotating to other teams is also nearly impossible. The culture is extremely toxic. Seniors and managers will tell you to your face you did a good job on something, only to tear you to shreds behind your back to the partners. Utilization goals and work life balance are both impossible. You will not realize how horrible it is to work at this company until you leave. I received more respect working in fast food than I did here. Leadership is the opposite of transparent. We were not informed about layoffs until 8am on the morning of layoffs. This company pays plenty of money to get ranked highly on different workplace rating articles, but let me assure you they view you as an input of labor and nothing else. Management does a horrendous job of planning out engagements and will always have you working until 3am the night before something is due, even if they knew about the deadline months in advance. The pay is obscenely below market and the bonus structure is pathetic.

cons:
Work/Life Balance - similar to any Big 4 firm, the job is demanding and high-stress. Not every experience is the same, nor is every busy season, but I've had my fair share of 90 hour weeks and nights working until 3:00 AM.

Compensation - standard for Big 4, but slightly behind industry, especially after the impact of COVID.

headline: Where do I even begin?? This review is for KPMG in Singapore (Advisory)
pros:
- Learning experience
- Variety of projects
- Good place to start your career (only from an experience perspective)
cons:
This review is for KPMG in Singapore, Advisory.

Where do I even begin? I would advise against reading any one-liner reviews you see on sites like Glassdoor. 

1. REMUNERATION AND STAFF RETENTION

It is a no-brainer that Big 4 pays below market especially for fresh graduates but you have no idea how appalling it can be for KPMG in Singapore. The Advisory pay structure is practically Audit pay structure with minor adjustments (Disclaimer: Don't get me wrong, there are plenty of very intelligent, friendly, nice, people in Audit but the value of Audit work in general cannot be compared to Advisory work, even though Audit revenues are generally steadier and less volatile than Advisory).

Hence, standard practice is to accept job offers here as a safety net, and then renege when you get better offers elsewhere. Even after starting work, juniors continuously apply to test the market for better offers. I know people who quit on the first day, after two weeks, within two months, within a year: so really, any time.

So junior turnover is extremely high. And you can imagine the burden this has on engagement delivery: juniors quit, teams have to re-hire, and then re-train the new hire. But while managers are training the new person, it means they have to help out on the grunt work themselves on top of the massive responsibilities they have as managers on admin, compliance, client management, etc. Eventually these managers themselves also quit.

It's a house of cards, really. How bad is the situation? In the Consulting arm of Advisory, some teams only have 1 to 3 juniors remaining (people who are Assistant Managers and below). Many people, especially juniors, left during and after an incredibly disappointing series of townhalls. First, people were promoted without a pay increase. Later, a pay increase was instituted for half a year, and only at half the amount of standard increments (i.e. half increment for half a year). No back-payment was promised. Can you imagine the disappointment? Yes, COVID made it difficult. But imagine a firm that cannot afford you a pay more despite already paying you so much lower than market average.

So I don't get why it is so difficult for management to understand the need to pay their staff better. It's even funnier when you discover some partners apparently believe that they pay above market. Their source? "A recruiter told me." The recruiter either has something against KPMG or is making you believe it in the hopes that this will indirectly cause unhappiness for some of your employees eventually, in turn making it easy for recruiters to target.

When my peers and juniors have become jaded at this company, I encourage them to look for jobs. I even know of people in other teams who forward job postings to their fellow teammates (manager to associate, for example). This is the toxic environment this firm has become although we have no malicious intent. We just want to support our colleagues who have become our friends.

2. JUNIOR PARTNERS HAVE A TOUGH LIFE TOO

When I say management, I really mean only senior partners and above. Junior partners and below have a terrible life. Junior partners find themselves trapped between resolving their team's problems and the need to avoid getting on the bad side of the more senior partners who are important to their career prospects (e.g. relationships with key accounts, relationships with industry, relationships within the broader global KPMG network).

When someone quits, junior partners ask "How can I make your life better?", and if the answer is "Pay me higher", they can only respond "Sorry, even I can't do that for you."

headline: Assistant Manager FS Tech
pros:
- Great name to have on the CV
- Community aspect to your team, you feel valued as a team member
- Great place to make friends and enjoy social engagements/meeting for drinks etc.
- Wide range of projects to get involved in
- Support/backing provided if you want to take on formal training/qualifications
- Lots of CSR opportunities
- Remote working options available
- Big client names
- Plenty of opportunities to get involved in internal work
cons:
- Work/life balance can be poor
- Realistically you are working 40+ hours every week
- You can be stuck on bad projects (particularly for the junior grades)
- Not enough senior positions are held by female or BAME representatives (progress is being made to address this)
- You can't expect to succeed/progress in this business by just doing project work. To be noticed/promoted you have to take on internal work (i.e. sales, thought leadership, proposition building etc.)
- Tough for junior grades to get involved in sales work
-

headline: Good start for corporate careers

cons: long hours (60+ hour weeks normal and weekends), work is mostly clerical and uninspiring, felt like managers were pestering the client and we were more of a value subtraction than addition. Most of your compensation is in the form of benefits and "experience", so if you don't get to enjoy the benefits or plan to work in corporate finance, this isn't the role for you.

headline: Good enough
pros:
KPMG as a big firm gives you the chance to try different areas. They are quite flexible when it comes to move towards another area after even 6 months. (better that than they lose you ;) )

If you are the kind of person looking for a "safe job" and get a reasonable salary comparing with Portugal's mean, you will be fine at KPMG. (not so good , because of extra hours tho).

Health insurance and Vodafone perks.
cons:
If you get out of a top university in Portugal and you look for something exciting, just go abroad and start in any consulting company instead. When it comes to salary Portugal's tax system is not attractive and wages are low. Apart from that in KPMG Portugal, the consulting mindset is completely distorted. You will not step up on your career based on your effort. There are minimum years required in each level. So even though you are amazing you will end up have to wait 3 to 4 years to step up.

Work-life balance isn't the worst, but still sucks. And keep in mind OVER WORK IS NOT PAID.

headline: Not the best
pros: Plenty of networking opportunities within the firm. Decent clients in the seatte market. The partner for advisory in the seatte office is really smart and approachable.
cons:
Career advisors (or PMLs) are useless.
No type of accountability for bad leadership. 
Upward feedback is zero to none here. 
Management listens to your problems but no action is ever taken. 
Not a very supportive working culture. 
They only hire by years of experience but not by actual performance. 
Transfers/experienced hires get paid wayyy more so I wouldn’t bother starting a career here.
Managers and directors are not approachable whatsoever and they run the office as a clique.

headline: Good place to start a career but will burn you out
pros:
KPMG is a great place to start a career and will help with job prospects later on. 
At KPMG, you may:
-meet some great people
-learn a lot
-network
-get exposed to a lot of different kinds of businesses
cons: Work life balance is awful during busy season and can be bad at times throughout the rest of the year. The firm culture perpetuates the idea that it doesn't matter how good you are at your job or how efficiently you work so long as you are working as many hours as everyone else. Efficiency is often rewarded with additional work.

headline: Great learning experience, sometimes tedious work
pros:
- Great opportunities to learn businesses and processes

- Exposure to multinational clients and senior management

- Clear career progression 

- Performance based progression and incentives

- Flexible working

- 9-5 for a good part of the year
cons:
- Sometimes tedious work, can get very repetitive unless you push for new challenges

- Difficult to manage work-life balance at times depending on the team/engagement you are on

- Expectation of long hours during busy/signing season (55-70hrs p/w)

- Small fish in a large pond, can be difficult to distinguish yourself and get recognition 

- Political nature of career progression

- Culture very team/department dependant. Coaching culture needs improvement.

headline: Highly political
pros: Almost guaranteed promotions. They promote almost everyone.
cons: Retention at senior associates and below is also horribly low because they are underpaid relative to market, so there is constant turnover and the good staff have fled to higher paying firms. They have since refreshed the ranks with new people who are higher paid (because they were hired at market) but will take at least a year to be fully functional. Guess who has to deal with that on their engagements.

headline: Still Not Getting It...
pros:
Brand name
Project exposure
Security and stability a large firm brings
Starting to clear out the sub par male, pale, stale leadership
cons:
Pay is awful
Bonus is embarrassing 
L&D opportunities aren’t there - unless you want to do CIMA or ACA there’s no chance of anything meaningful, no masters sponsorship etc
This is no exaggeration, five - ten years behind on the digital agenda. Utterly clueless
Fragmented - partners scrapping for revenue and status. 
Partners are generally nothing special, very few intellectual powerhouses in the firm, mostly sales focussed individuals that were fortuitously aligned to a big-revenue client earlier in their career 
Some partners genuinely view the world in terms of ‘winners’ and ‘losers’ - it would be cringe if it wasn’t so toxic 
Politics are unbearable 
If a partner takes a dislike to you, you may as well resign, seen many careers ruined
Promotions are a joke - there are people who are performing for 1 yr + at the grade above and still cannot get promoted. There have been people selling a lot of work that still get turned down
When you do go for promotion you are put through an interview process and have to provide a business case at even Manager level (something you literally cannot control, given it depends on the work you are aligned to)
Systems are so outdated and lead to a ton of admin
Very much a conform or leave agenda in terms of culture
D&I initiatives more oriented towards protecting partners from embarrassing headlines than actually addressing D&I issues - there have been no substantial policy changes in recruitment for example. 
The consulting practice is basically an advisory firm - generalists do not progress. If you want to progress you need to specialise in a certain, very specific area, which kind of defeats the reason why many people go into consulting in the first place. 
Quality of work is painfully variable - I’ve seen some work that can rival MBB and other work that is so poor I’m almost embarrassed for the client receiving it

headline: Never join KGS MC Team
pros: Nothing which I can think of
cons:
I joined KGS few years back, and man what a bumpy ride it is... I belong to their Management Consulting (MC) wing. The Management there is corrupt to the core, which was evident by the removal of a Director and few Managers from the team, when they were expelled from the company on account of taking bribes to get in some of their disciples into the firm. Someone from their own clan disclosed this and on a December winter, few of those chaps were caught off guard. And off they went out from the firm, Poof!!!

After that, a good for nothing Senior Manager, who didn't had any experience in handling a large team was made the head of the team and obviously, in his tenure the number of projects dwindled and almost all of them went to pipeline. The upper management woke up from their sleep and recruited a new Senior Manager after this. This new guy has come from another service based firm, which is notorious for regionalism and favouritism, and sure enough he had started the same behaviour in KGS too. That was evident from the team structure now, as most of the 'top performers' according to him, was from the same region from which he belongs. Obviously good and talented team members are avert to this, and they started either changing the team or left KGS altogether. This is the current stage of the KGS MC team, and I won't recommend any one to join it, unless you are good in buttering up the Managers. HR, as usual, are not conducive of the employees, but of the upper Management and you will be threatened to be put in Performance Improvement Plan, even if you are performing well. The new senior manager also pressurize the immediate managers to ask for the long tenured employees to leave the organization by setting them unachievable targets. If you have buttered him up and haven’t achieved your targets, that's not a problem. But for the others who genuinely work and who don’t know buttering up, like me, its a hell hole. I am still stuck here, and will be out of this hell as soon as I see something cooking up for me outside.

headline: No Career Growth or Future - KPMG GSOC Noida
pros:
You will be getting free cabs [Not shared ones]

Best place to learn how to survive the most toxic environment.
cons:
Excessive micromanagement. 

You will have to justify every single second of your day and even if there is no such work, you will be asked to generate work by yourself.

No recognition to hard-working and skilled employees. Awards and appreciations are for favorites only.

Too much politics on all levels of management.

There is only Data entry work in the name of Cyber Security. If you're coming here for learning new things, you're going to regret the whole time.

You will be forced to work on your off days too and will be questioned for taking sick leaves.

The management here believes in QUANTITY but not Quality.

From Analyst to Shift Lead, everyone has the exact same responsibility i.e Data Entry work. Payout is the only difference here.

Management does not trust their employees.

Very unprofessional and bossy people leading the teams who don't know how to behave with their fellow colleagues.

Management doesn't value the feedback from their employees and nothing is going to change here.

cons:
Remuneration is poor. Having started as a graduate in 2015, it seems you have to move in order to get the sort of pay your progression in skill and responsibility merits.

The company is currently caught between a flagging audit giant and a fledgling technology company - and is poorer for the indecisive leadership. Talented technologists are rare at KPMG and often leave when they realise there are more inviting and well-paid opportunities elsewhere.

headline: Great team, good company, average pay
pros: The team I work with is by far one of the best - upper management has clear direction and communicates this direction well, I am empowered to deliver my best. The company itself and pay is considered average, but considering how decisions were made to not furlough staff or make anyone redundant during the pandemic, I think this is a great decision that was made by the Exec team - which shows that they value their employees. Alot of headway being made with I&D which is also great. Loads of career opportunities and leadership is always encouraging, challenging staff to explore.
cons: Despite the culture of the company the brand feels a bit old and tired. Pay is pretty average and the bonus amount was small but at least it was something.

headline: Tax: For data-focused professionals
pros:
- The salary and benefits are solid. Not amazing with low bonuses, but steady and you can expect steady raises as you get promoted.
- Network is fantastic internally and for the accounting/consulting industry. Less so for tech-minded
- Vast resources for tools and training, blowout company events like Lake House training and Holiday events
cons:
-Data literacy and capabilities is well behind the times, especially in certain silos. 
-Limited in early career data roles. Overall, I would not call it a mature data company. They are trying, but the adoption seems to be moving slowly.
-Too much focus at individual level on utilization rates

headline: Great Big Company. Work Hard. Play Hard.
pros: KPMG pays for tons of travel for the client, training conferences, courses, etc. They also give you chargeable time for this and chargeable time to volunteer. Eventful socials, parties, and Summer time get-off-work early kickbacks, Plus, two weeks given off company-wide during the holidays? Wow
cons: You will work sometimes long hours. In the Federal Practice to get promoted, you basically need to live in the National Capitol Region. Your supervisor may not even work with you, but is responsible for your annual reviews.... You must remain billable. Hopefully your city has business booming in your Department or else be ready to relocate.

headline: Honest review
pros:
Good work life balance than other big 4s
Good learning opportunity & good exposure
cons:
Lot of office politics
It’s all a matter of perception. If you are perceived as good by your manager, you can submit a poem in the name of a report and he will be happy. 
However, if you are not perceived as good but are very hard working and intelligent, whatever brilliant output you produce, your manager will always grade you badly in the performance cycle

headline: Fantastic growth
pros:
1. Fantastic growth 
2. A company which cares about people 
3. If you perform well, you will be compensated both monetarily and career wise 
4. You’ll get all the support you require. All you need to do is - ask for it
cons:
1. You need a certain X factor to survive and be successful. There’s a certain lively, buzzing work culture that is in the fabric of the company. If you are Mr/Ms outside hire you will struggle to adapt.
2. It’s easy to get lost on one long project and not learn anything in 2 years. Make sure you speak to people from your department/ service line. Especially those who you don’t work with

headline: KPMG GDC Audit Associate
pros: Good infrastructure, nice campus, cafeteria. Work wise nothing
cons: I worked with KPMG gdc for 3 years. January to March is busy season they make you work at least 13 hours a day. No importance to imployees they make people work like slaves. Approval of leaves is totally depend on TL. Manager has no say in anything manager is nothing but a toy. Everything is managed by director. TL is just like a normal associate. You make a mistake they treat you like a traitor. You won't learn anything with GDC just copy paste work. If you use your brain in your work manager is the 1st one to ask questions. You do as you told anything extra will fetch you an error and impact your performance.

headline: Don't bother coming to work here
pros: None that I can think of
cons:
1. You'll be working for 10+ hours everyday for the same pay other companies give with a much better work life balance.
2. They expect you to be able to respond to email 24*7 and even on weekend, even if you're at low level.
3. If you want a promotion, you're expected to put in twice the amount of normal hours and show to management that you work late every night. 
4. Whether you're in management consulting or technology (I've been in both) you will not learning any new skills and will have a lot of trouble when trying to switch.

Basically, you'll be putting in twice the amount of effort and hours for the same pay you can get in any other company.

headline: Hugely Overestimated
pros: Most of people are great to work with
cons:
Qualification: you are only given very limited time to study, and you can easily be fired if you fail the exam. Over half of my intake were fired.

Workload: you will never get a good work life balance.

Administration: you have to borrow money for business trip. It can take ages for the manager to approve your expense.

They only have a very high integrity standards against their employees, not to their clients. Anyone pay PwC for a good audit, please have a look at smaller firm.

Management: manager can ask you work till 2am for a promotion. Your bonus is totally depended on your manager.

Environment: Respectful environment in lower level. The higher level you get, the less diversity you see.

headline: Access to tons of different experiences
pros: If you're a good performer and willing to look around, there are tons of different experiences through PwC. I'm focused on Audit, but was also loaned to a large bank to work in their internal audit department, had a 4 month work transfer to California (from Canada), eventually moved to San Francisco, and am now working on an internal project. I've raised my hand for new opportunities, and have been able to travel internationally, and build great experience working with diverse teams. Sure, audit can be intense, but if you take advantage of the down time, speak up for yourself and your schedule, and be open and proactive in seeking out new opportunities, it's worth it. I've been fortunate to work with amazing people that really do care. I never planned to stay this long, but each time I find myself thinking of moving externally, I'm able to find a different project or experience that gets me excited again. It's like anything -you need to own your own experience and be proactive.
cons: It's easy to get overworked, and to overwork your teams. Classic Big 4 complaints, but it's encouraging to see the initiatives the company is investing in to improve this.

headline: PwC Operate - Would not recommend
pros: Most co-workers are bright, hard working and easy to get along with
cons:
In no way shape or form could working at PwC Operate be considered a graduate job. The majority of the projects you are assigned to are glorified data entry roles - having a degree in your job requirements is baffling. If you are lucky enough to get onto a challenging project that's interesting, management and senior staff will make sure to push you and push you until you have nothing left to give, with over time and long hours always expected - not asked for. 

There also seems to a bit of a cult mentality about the place, the only people who are recognised are those who are not necessarily the best, but those who blow the PwC trumpet about how great of a place it is to work for and how much it's changed their life - like the brand ambassadors.

headline: A reasonable start to any graduate’s career, but not a great long term prospect
pros:
- Friendly staff and good atmosphere
- Some interesting projects and opportunities to develop skills
- Most projects don’t require much overtime
- Good flexibility offered (working from home, etc)
cons:
- Lack of progression long term
- Management are a clique, and have their favourites who get by doing very little and are the ones who get progressed. If you are outside the tent you are largely forgotten.
- This clique divide correlates between the people who actually do the critical work and those who spend more time in meetings talking about doing work.
- Pay is below average, particularly once you have a year or two’s experience.

headline: Great people, caring environment
pros: PwC hire fantastic people, and everyone goes out of their way to help. The office environment is friendly, and small enough for you to get to know nearly everyone. There are plenty of opportunities to get involved and there is always something going on. I feel like everyone really does put their team first and although there is a lot of work, you are always supported by your colleagues. There are many training opportunities so you can learn quickly. The firm is investing heavily in tech and constantly improving the tech environment to make work easier and more efficient.
cons: There is a lot to take in and because the progression of the graduate scheme is fast, you often feel that you are being stretched. Some jobs can feel understaffed so everyone always has a lot on their plate. The salary isn't the best compared to other grad schemes outside public accounting, however you receive a lot of training and time not working to study for exams, which the firm pays for.

headline: Fake it until you make it
pros:
They have a good online educational system. You can find there a lot of useful lectures and materials and if you finish a course they will give you an officila PWC certificate of completion.
The office building from the outside.
One year counts as two ( but read the cons to understand why )
cons:
The office building from the inside. It reminds me of a nest of cockroaches, so many people so little space. They really care about their status but do not think about the conditions they put people in. For example, they could afford a bigger and more modern office a little bit further for the same price, but they stay in this mole pit because they want people to be impressed because the location in the center of the city is more important for them than the space for the employees. 
The corporate culture is crippled by the people turnover, managers and senior consultants understand they quite a few can indulge such conditions so they do not care about positive attitude or creating a healthy atmosphere. They always try to see the negative, scheme and plot, focus only on bad sides. The first week I worked there a n employeee tried to set me up and make a joke in fornt of a partner (thank good he was not clever nor schrewd ) I understood and stopped him. 
The salary of course is very low and will rise to the standart level only in several years. With the basic salary you barely can pay your bills. 
Working over hours was not a problem but you should be prepared for that.
The coffe and tea tasted like mud - not significant but important for understanding how the company tries to squeeze the last cent from every corner to pay for the "status"

headline: Mixed bag - depends on your priorities
pros:
- work with big clients on impressive deals 
- reputable and good exit opportunities because of the brand name
- fantastic training and network of support - people are clearly driven, clever and hard-working
 - opportunities to transfer to other lines of service via Transfer Window - lots of other professional services you could do at the Big 4, i.e. good options if you want to broaden your skillset.
cons:
- long hours for not enough compensation as opposed to competition or the industry. They are very aware that you are working for them because of the brand name and so know they can get away with offering mediocre compensation.
 - a 'look busy' all the time sort of culture and 'showing face' to clients by going to client site when not necessary
 - they preach a lot about mental health and wellbeing at the firm, but its the long hours and hard deadlines that's the main cause of the issue. They will sometimes accept unrealistic deadlines set by the client, expecting you to work crazy hours to meet it when, in reality, they can just negotiate better in favour of our teams.
 - they encourage you try other roles and expand skillset but if you tried to manage your own diary, there isn't that much flexibility in terms of which clients you can be on (luck of the draw sometimes) and whether you can work on other lines of service temporarily/on secondments.

headline: Unsuitable for technology enthusiasts
pros:
- Supportive and friendly working culture
- Fair benefits
- Flexible working hours on most of the projects
- Excellent place to try many finance and accounting related projects
cons:
- Everyone treated as generalists in first 3 years, no one (really) cares if you have specific skillset or interests. So you end up doing whatever job is available and was not taken by anyone more experienced. Resourcing system is supposed to match people to jobs based on their skills and interests, but that just does not work - there are too many "mundane/repetitive" audit/assurance type projects that many people end up stuck with (rather than actual technology or data analytics projects)
- Very opaque, complicated and politicised higher level team structures. What kind of job you will have access to heavily depends on which partner is governing your team, rather than on your and your team's particular purpose and skillsets.

headline: Great people, company, and experience, BUT pay is well below market
pros:
1) PEOPLE - I have met many of my best friends at PwC. I will never forget the first few years specifically. This has easily been the best part of my job.

2) EXPERIENCE - I have learned A LOT in my first few years and I don't think I could have had this level of experience anywhere else. I remember starting on day 1 like a chicken with its head cutoff. Now I'm running the client and team meetings, coaching associates, running the audit, and multitasking between jobs.

3) LEADERSHIP - I believe that the leadership team is good overall and keeps me drinking the Kool-Aid. I like what they stand for too.

4) REMOTE WORK - Work form home during COVID for foreseeable future.

5) EXIT OPS - Since being promoted to Senior Associate, the exit job opportunities have been vast. Feels like I'm getting blasted a new opportunity almost every other day. Tempting...
cons:
1) PAY - This is below market average. I'm making roughly $60k as a Senior Associate when similar jobs in industry pay $75-80k. 

2) TURNOVER - The worst part of my experience. Turnover is very high which creates a lot of extra work for your position when your team members leave. It happens every year too.

3) HOURS - You get worked very hard. This is expected at a Big Four. I don't mind it when the work is interesting, but I'm weird like that.

4) TIERING SYSTEM - PwC ranks you against your class (Associates, Seniors, etc.) at the end of the fiscal year. Unfortunately, my situation doesn't allow for higher tiering within the system and ultimately has kept my pay relatively low.

headline: Exploitation as a Business Model
pros: Great quality people and connections. This organization is a sales, management, and relationship company above all. They are not the best at what they do (despite the polished constant stream of fluff internal and external marketing). They rely pretty much entirely on their pre-existing financial assurance relationships to sell more work. Lots of opportunity to work in a wide variety of areas and industries so long as you keep active in your relationship building. Pretty easy business case to train and grow. Be decisive and stay committed to your intended career direction, and try not to be too flexible or you'll get easily lost. Speak up and be real about what you want - the coaching culture and support was amazing and will pleasantly surprise you if you pick your relationships right. Get what you need (training, relationships, exposure) and get out (unless you want to make partner). Lots of free and excellent training opportunities. Good parties for the young ones (pre-COVID). Pick your team wisely.
cons:
Hit and miss opportunities. Often you don't get to pick what you want to do, so you have to be OK with floating in the wind; subject to the whims of whatever client gets snagged in the marketing snares. Org structure makes things ridiculous - you'll probably report to 20 managers at some point who seem to make an active point of not talking to each other to actually resource manage (despite the titles). You will work long hours because of this ineffective management style. Very top heavy and political once you see through the fluff marketing. Meetings are nearly all day past a certain point, leaving barely any room to get any actual work done. The company does NOT value actual work (only sales and profits) and WILL treat you like a cog to be exploited as much as possible to a fault. The company is not as clever as they think they are in terms of its exploitative nature, and a complete inability to retain good people that actually get work done will be its eventual downfall. Peter principle reigns. HR is virtually non-existent. Titles are laughable - directors will have one or two managers reporting to them, each of which is most likely a glorified project manager and will be lucky to have any staff reports at all (despite external appearances). 

So brain-washy it isn't even funny. If you start your career here you won't even know the difference (by design). Don't get caught up and be very mindful of any non-chargable "make work" admin overhead company initiatives. They are 99.9% ploys by a director or partner to make them look good on the back of your personal "voluntold" time. Exploitation and team building on their own don't work when the entire company is doing it to each other, so there's nobody left to actually do the work. Que more overtime.

headline: Culture of overtime; limited opportunities
pros: Great firm to have on your resume, in turn opening doors to other places; high-performing environment which in turn allows for you to learn good skills; colleagues are, for the most part, all impressive and good at what they do; positive experience to the extent you are in a caring, collegial team; it's possible you can avoid excessive overtime (but you may be disadvantaged by doing so); very inclusive for LGBTIQ.
cons: Culture of overtime (I have been told there is an expectation of overtime and PwC is not a 9-5 business); prioritises output over quality, such that you will be disadvantaged if you don't/can't work overtime (and, as a result, I frequently see people who work 24/7 but produce only average work get promoted over people who have better technical skills and produce high-quality work, but can't do crazy hours), and as such not a good environment for a primary carer; some senior people are so focused on being partner (or performing well upon recent admission) that they'll act with zero care, tolerance or compassion to those around them; rather than opening up doors within the organisation, often teams are quite insular and partners will fight to stop you leaving (and it's unlikely you can go anywhere without them backing you); teams are quite specialised such that your skill set can limit your opportunities for more generalist roles; pretty average pay until you're at least senior manager (terrible pay at the junior levels); relatively slow progression; lots of diversity and inclusion policies but many of these are just on paper (ultimately an old school firm that expects blood and rewards those who can give it over, say, those that need to care for kids). Note that the above may be team/department-specific to some extent.

headline: Good Experience Professionally, Horrible Management
pros: Having the name PwC opens up a lot of doors for you, and you gain exceptional experience.. worth it for a few years and to get your CPA license for free.
cons: Horrible hours. You’re expected to have no life for two months or more out of your year. I worked multiple weeks for over 90 hours and made myself sick trying to get everything done. Expected to work sometimes even if you’re technically on vacation. Horrible pay for how much you work. Every single person I know that has left has gotten at least a 20K increase in salary for less hours. Management has completely unreasonable expectations and doesn’t actually know how to manage people because the company does a poor job at training leaders. Management treats people like crap when they leave if it’s not in managements best interest. The list of cons goes on and on.

headline: Work Life Balance is bad - but the rest is not
pros: Connections, you meet a lot of people and its interesting to get to team across different practice areas and different networks. Shows you how small the world is and helps you practice your communication and teaming. Most people are young or open minded which helps keeps things interesting, and in non-covid times makes it feasible to get along with your colleagues.
cons: Work life balance is rough, its very typical to be overstaffed on projects and in addition feel like there isn't much of a slow down. Even if things do slow down, its never enough to feel refreshed or maybe you would even be punished for not being utilized enough just because someone else in the firm is in their typical busy season and you finished yours // work in consulting and dont have a busy season.

headline: Modern Slavery
pros: False sense of career progression
cons: Tone-deaf leadership that is that is willfully ignorant to the realities of its employees. Dehumanizing compensation considering the stress and workload that comes with this job. I'm truly mentally scarred from this experience. They prey on new, insecure college graduates who don't know any better, and pay them below market rate for life-shortening, mundane tasks that trained monkeys can perform. No one really has time to coach you since the managers themselves are drowning from work. The tasks are not particularly hard, but it's the volume, people who don't know how to manage/communicate, lack of REAL support that is causing so much suffering.

headline: Great place to be if you enjoy a structured, competitive environment
pros: Solid organizational infrastructure, room to grow and build a career, smart and hard-working colleagues.
cons: Big 4 culture is pretty stereotypical and well-known. You will work a lot. The hours will be long. Everyone else around you will be working a lot, and this never changes as you move up the ladder, so you have to be prepared to make the job the primary focus of your life. They're actively trying to promote work-life balance, and doing a decent job, but the culture is so ingrained at this point that it will never be a relaxed 9-5 type of environment.

headline: A great company for those looking for a well-rounded business & technically oriented experience
pros:
- Opportunities to work in a vast range of different sectors, and a vast range of types of projects
- Regardless of where you are currently staffed, you have the chance to work in other compentencies as long as you make the right connections and have the right skillsets
- Significant amount of internal resources available for employees to upskill themselves - everything from soft-consulting skills & project management skills, to more technical things such as Python, system-specific courses, sector-specific concepts, etc.
cons:
- As with any firm engaged in consulting services, there are a variety of different metrics that each employee is judged against every evaluation cycle, and sometimes it can be tough keeping up with everything that is required
- The firm is constantly coming up with new tools and processes to improve the way we work, which is great, but sometimes this "innovation" is a bit much, and teams responsible for delivering with these new ideas get lost on what they should be using and exactly how to derive value from each tool
-

headline: Interned to Full Time
pros: Great opportunities to learn, work with smart people in a community that is inclusive and supportive. A big thing PwC pushes is "Be Well, Work Well" which helps some with work-life balance as they understand the strain we are managing. Personally, the mantra of PwC is something I love - "Our purpose is to solve complex problems and promote trust in society." They don't just put that on a billboard in the office, it feels like something PwC is driven and focused on doing which makes me a proud employee.
cons: Challenging work, you have to be a self motivator, willing to learn and apply yourself. Work-life balance can be difficult to manage. I've found that success is found through a sink or swim approach. You have to get up and volunteer to get things done and form relationships that will want to work with you in the future. There are tons of resources and support, you just have to be proactive in utilizing them. I often dream of retirement and or changing jobs to something less demanding but I feel the personal growth and professional experience is worth it.

headline: Good place to be overall, but rigid hierarchical structure

- Business development over everything else: client is always right, even if they’re not

headline: It's an audit firm

- Salary 
- Work life balance is far worse than they pretend they are aiming for
- It's an audit firm first, then a risk assurance firm ... MC is near the bottom of the list. 
- Strategy& pretend they are superior to MC (having worked with many of them ... they aren't)
- there is a large distribution of skillsets from 'struggles to tie their own shoelaces' to fantastic ... you never know what you are going to get when you take on a new associate.

pros:
- Amazing client base with unparalleled opportunities. Ability to work across different industries, with different clients and in locations across the world provides variety and great career development
- Travel opportunities (if you want it) - been able to work across Europe, ME, US and Asia which has been incredibly rewarding
- People culture - collaborative, friendly colleagues (from all backgrounds) and leadership. You'll make friends for life at PwC. Firm will always offer you support when you need it.
- Great progression opportunities - you'll be promoted as soon as you can demonstrate performance at the grade above
-High performing and driven colleagues motivate you to be your best
-The power of the brand - with time at PwC you'll always be employable
cons:
- Compensation below Director level feels misaligned to the responsibilities and pressures that come with the role. This is no 9-5 job and for extended periods it can be difficult to maintain a work-life balance - but support is always there.
- To perform at the top levels, a considerable contribution over and above your full time client facing role is required (though this varies across the business) - BD, capability development etc, which can make work-life balance difficult at times
- Can be difficult for experienced hires with no network - relationships and reputation key to get the best roles

headline: Good place to start a career
pros:
You'll gain a really good baseline of professionalism - time management, client interaction, presentations, note-taking, 'managing up', how to learn quickly, quality work quality, etc.

There's also VAST amount of learning resources - you can find training on a variety of different technologies, expertises, etc.

The pay isn't so bad either, especially if you're traveling as you can basically expense your living (sans rent) for four days a week.
cons:
They preach work-life balance by emphasizing that you shouldn't be working too long on client engagements...but then expect you to contribute 1-5 hours per day on 'reinvest' work. Business dev, internal stuff, thought leadership...in many sense they expect you to pick up a part-time job on top of your full-time job

As with any large corporation, you begin to feel like just a number and that you're contributing work to a huge, vast enterprise and you can't see your impact. It's really hard to get promoted unless your a total type A and on top of everything / willing to sell your soul to it.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: Amazing, hard working people. You'll learn more in your first couple years than your peers will learn in 5+ years. More free time and flexibility in the summer/fall after busy season. Opportunities to manage others early in your career. One of the few companies that didn't have to let anyone go during covid and still managed to give us raises. Very pleased I started my career here.
cons: Busy season hours can be very long, although I have gotten lucky before and had a few 40 hour weeks. Not a place I plan on staying for more than 3 years.

headline: Fantastic first job
pros: Brilliant training and opportunities to work with C-Suite staff in your first few years. Firm invests in your growth and HR will support you (particularly through covid or health issues). Company health policy provides over £1k worth of therapy a year if needed and private medical insurance. Such a huge firm you are exposed to thousands of opportunities and brilliant staff/social events if you’re moving to a new city.
cons:
Below average pay for the sector (paying for the name and exit opportunities).
PwC picks safe projects to minimise the risk to brand and reputation which often means they can be boring multi-year engagements.
Standardised promotion pathways and no-performance based bonuses for the first 3 years means there’s limited monetary incentives.
Can feel as if you’re a ‘small cog in a big machine’ 
Sector/type of work is region dependent. Regional offices often specialise where has London has more opportunity for Finance or Private brands.
Some projects require a lot of hours (others don’t, and you have choice in this)

cons:

- Continuous efforts by management to reduce the benefits and/or pay to staff in order to increase the profit towards the partners
- Poor work/life balance especially from January to June
- Incompetent people are being promoted because many competent people leave the company for better opportunities (higher pay / better work life balance / ...)

headline: Big4 is a BigTrap
pros: Onboarding and training programs are good. But I guess those are made to make you feel good for really bad times ahead.
cons:
- Too much favoritism - If you blindly agree to each and everything your boss says without any complaint, then this is the best place to work. But you have to sell your soul, your family time and your health.
- Work life balance is the worst and you don't get paid enough. 
- Limited and non transferable skills - You do quantitative, manual work and become obsolete. The more time you spend with these firm, the more it becomes difficult for you to move out.

headline: Deals Experience Assosicate
pros: Amazing place to work. Gain a lot of knowledge and skills. The 95% of the culture is fantastic. Very progressive company with great executive leadership that cares about their staff. Incredibly diverse and a lot of investment is made to ensure Black, Hispanic, and other groups are supported and connected.
cons:
Pay can push away great talent
System for promotion review can be very biased
Career does not progress relative to overtime hours. You will not feel like it was worth stressing yourself by taking on initiatives and projects.

headline: Worst culture, welfare and job scope ever!
pros: The pantry, the pantry lady, the cleaner, and the peers who end up leaving with you. Those are the good ones.
cons:
If you’re a fresh graduate thinking that you’ve landed a prestigious job at a Big 4 firm, think again. Your starting pay of 3.0k is subject to around a 1.2 months bonus. Meanwhile all your peers with a GPA comparable or even below yours are earning 4-5k. Market rate. I’ve since landed jobs that pay 4.5 and above after staying in pwc for barely half a year. There is no such coaching culture as they like to preach, once you’re dumped in right after the 2 week inadequate zoom training, you’re expected to be as a good as a second year associate. Less than 3 in 10 people in the firm would actually explain anything to you, yet you’ll get scolded and marked down whenever you cannot explain the nature behind certain accounting documentation and testing. 

There is no welfare, during peak which lasts around 3-6 months (depending on which firms u r “lucky” enough to be assigned to audit), you are expected to work beyond 996. More like 9am- 12 midnight, you won’t get to spend time with you family and friends except (maybe)Friday night. 

There is a Roundtable every May or so, where the managers will have a meeting and faces of every associate and senior associate in the department will be flashed on a screen and be criticised and evaluated whether they should be promoted. This is stab in the back sort of politics. So if you’re lucky, your 3.0k pay might be upgraded to 3.3k if you do manage to promote. Hearsay 5 people did not promote last year due to this and COVID. So kenna 3.0k one more round while all your peers from other industries gunning for high 4 to Low 5s already. 

They conduct such stringent interviews, but the truth is the attrition rate is mortifying. During the week I left, I checked through others leaving as well because you can do so on the GTS booking on their Google calendar under “off boarding”. Every week since Jan, they would be like 10-15 people leaving on a Friday. People don’t even want their bonus in June because working for this firm is worse than the measly 40k we get a year. Prospects are not too good too! I ended up leaving the accounting industry completely and am now very happy and earning almost twice what I used to earn.

headline: Employee waste of time
pros: PricewaterhouseCoopers is a multinational professional services network of firms, operating as partnerships under the PwC brand. PwC ranks as the second-largest professional services network in the world and is considered one of the Big Four accounting firms, along with Deloitte, EY and KPMG
cons:
Interview process is very slow.
After clear all the rounds no response from PWC side and last telling like currently posotion goes on hold. waste of employee time.
Don't expect to get response from them on time.
Do not wait if offer letter didn't received in 1 week.

headline: PWC has the potential to be a great company but chooses not to
pros: PWC hires the best and brightest employees who often go on to become industry leaders.
cons: PWC is located in expensive buildings who pay college graduates near minimum wage. Someone could make more money working at Discount Auto Parts. The only difference is one will go home dirty and the other will go home clean.

headline: Offers great career opportunities but at the cost of work-life balance
pros:
Brilliant exam support through the tax learning & development team, flexwork policy specific to accounting / tax exams in advance of study leave. 
Continuous training re. people skills & tax technical knowledge.
Opportunities to work on large clients and complex projects. 
Approachable people including at the most senior levels, for the most part.
Good support available for people through the coach / appraiser and partner 'buddy' systems.
There is a willingness to invest in you and your career - partner 'buddy' system in place to have career discussions with people at the most senior levels - openness to facilitate secondments in Ireland / abroad, and career breaks/time off to travel after exams.
Great social events.
cons:
Very difficult to have work-life balance as you progress toward Manager level and above. It is acknowledged as an issue and there is a flex work policy in place at all levels that has somewhat helped. But at the end of the day the workloads are significant and can be relentless at times - as is the nature of the Big 4.

No access to the firm's pension plan - regardless of level - until you are 30. Ongoing issue for most employees under 30 who can be anything up to Senior Manager level, i.e. 8-9 years with the firm and no access to pension. You are provided a contact to set up a PRSA but there is no willingness to lower the age limit for entry to the pension plan.

headline: Look great on the outside but rotten on the inside
pros: Company came with great name brand and reputation. Great for college grads to be part of a Big-4 to learn, gain experience, and carry the firm name later in their career.
cons: Prepare to work crazy hours like a dog, being bullied and yelled at, unappreciated like a slave, and almost at minimum wage for a few years. Then, hope to get on the partner track or leave for greener pastures to make some money. Busy seasons require 60+hr/week minimum. But unfortunately for the tech team, they have 12 month busy season, so working 60+hr/week all year around. Everyone is to service the pleasure of his/her emperor, aka Partner, with a promise of an annual bonus which often a huge disappointment.

headline: Outsourced Global Mobility Specialist
pros: Saying you have a job experience on your CV, just like if you worked for any other company in the world.
cons:
PricewaterHouseCoopers outsources to developing countries and exploits people abroad. Here is what happened when I worked for them in South America:

-They treated outsourced employees as their slaves.
-Paid below poverty line wages (my salary was 4 thousand dollars A YEAR. I was basically a volunteer that worked 9 hrs per day for them).
-Coworkers that didn't have privileged families were malnourished and didn't have enough money to pay for water & electricity, therefore they wouldn't shower to go to work.
-People work in offices full of rats. 
-We didn't have any windows, the offices were literally bunkers.
-You weren't allowed to go to the bathroom.
-You got tracked & monitored all day long, second by second. If you stopped working for one minute they would threaten you.
-Completely unrealistic deadline expectations that no human being could tolerate.
-You got sexually and psychologically harassed, especially as a woman.

I saw so many cases of harassment and suicide attempts in their Latin American offices. It was completely insane to work for such an unethical company as PricewaterhouseCoopers US (Tampa).

They also make you sign huge confidentiality agreements because everything they do abroad goes against onshore and offshore laws, their employer branding and corporate values. PwC is a company made in hell and everyone should be aware of that before choosing to work for them.

Quite ironically, they are actually hiring sons & daughters of diplomats and officials of human rights organisations that of course, speak native English. How else do you think they speak so well, PwC? Since they are global citizens, they are ten times more educated than the people that exploit them in their United States offices...this world is straight up turned upside down. I don't know how such horrible and uneducated people can have so much power. You should be ashamed of all your violations.

*This review has nothing to do with the company that outsources: all of the violations came from PwC's commands and insistence of creating horrible work conditions that would be unacceptable in the United States. If they did this in their own country, they would all be put in jail.

headline: Good first job
pros:
1. Easy entry to associate level roles especially if you come from campus recruitment. 
2. Great reality check on getting used to the number of hours people work in accounting/finance as you’ll be working 9-3am at least a few times a year (which is normal even on the client side). It’s just the nature of this actg field. 
3. Culture is great. Everyone is on board with the millennial corporate culture. No one will ever embarrass you or others for being bad at your job. Overall, everyone is very nice and willing to help. Even if they truly don’t want to help, everyone is obligated to help because it’s just the culture at this firm. 
4. Flexibility - the transfer process is super easy if you know the right people. I’ve been able to work in different service lines as a result. 
5. Promotion is pretty much guaranteed and timeline based. You put in the number of years and you’ll get it. You wouldn’t be held back from a promotion unless people absolutely hate you or you’re so bad at the job that you literally can’t be promoted. From what I’ve seen, you can be average and still get promoted even at the manager level. It’s all a seniority game at the end of the day.
cons:
1. The firm constantly tries to adopt new changes which creates inefficiencies and zero value add. It all seems more for marketing purposes than for actual enhancements to the day to day job. 
2. Too many firm initiatives that are just for show rather than practice. For example, “be well work well, stop the grind” slogan has been tossed around the firm for the last year or so but I haven’t seen anyone actually “stop the grind.” People are consistently working every minute of the day and will get pings during their vacation time. It’s just the nature of the job as this is a client service field. 
3. I don’t think the work necessarily translates well into industry as this is a client service field where companies come here to buy specific services that they do not want to do or have enough human bodies to crank out. The longer you stay the harder it will be to exit this field unless you’re set you want to be here for 10+ years (which might not be bad).

headline: Culture problems
pros:
- Can work from home.
- Good benefits package.
cons:
- So siloed, hierarchical, and automated that it's impossible sometimes to find a solution to a problem. Higher level employees act like stingy gatekeepers of information and will even block you from achieving your goals if they feel threatened. 
- Constant IT issues that can take months to resolve.
- Casual sexism still rampant. If you are a woman, especially a minority woman, expect your ideas and work to be stolen and used by a peer or manager. If you have technical knowledge and expertise, it will be ignored because you don't look the part (male). 
- Very few growth opportunities for IFS. You will be expected to stay in your box. If any growth is discussed, it will be a strict line within your group. (So for example, if you're an admin but learned how to write Python, you still won't be encouraged to find a role outside of admin or, rarely, admin-management.) Bias comes into play here as well. Men in lower-level roles seem to be encouraged to branch out more than women are.
- Class and role bias very prevalent. You're judged by your title and not by what you can do. Higher level employees can be very abusive and they are rarely punished.
- The way bonuses and raises are distributed causes people to be very competitive, insecure, and scheming. Some behave unethically. 
-Leadership keeps critical information secret and feeds us untrue, carefully crafted lines to keep us complacent. 
- The firm values are virtue signalling, not of actual importance to the firm.
- Very "do as I say, not as I do."
- No mentoring system.
- Partners vote against their own interests and then complain and abuse employees when the changes they voted for take place.

headline: Unless you want to worship the Partners as gods
pros: Flexwork flexdress good medical coverage and office location
cons:
Great place to learn because nobody knows anything we all learn together, nobody knows if we are learning the things right.

Long serving staffs are retained and protected because they are long serving not performance driven and they are the toxic workers that stay around gossiping while new blood have to slog out to compensate for long serving staffs’ lack of calibre. 

Partners call the shots, needs to be worshipped like gods, very mountain tortoise style as they have never seen the outside world nor do they need to see.

Company has HR consulting arm but in house HR is in a total mess with sky high turnover. Complete irony. 

People wear the OT culture like a badge of honour, not sure if they are really productive busy during officer hours or just lazy and sloppy. Always the same few that works very hard (late).

headline: Modern slavery at its best
pros:
- some projects are interesting and challenging
- somtimes you will get significant dose of independance and you will be left to your own (pros if you like this kind of set-up)
- many smart people on a board
cons: This is really an example of modern slavery, where a small number of people on a top create a clique. Nobody controls them, they have absolute power, and they will do everything to realize their goal: earn more, more and more money as long as possible! It creates very clientelism system, cut-throat atmosphere, mobbing basically everywhere! It really doesn't matter how good are you, only political connections matter. Employees below Manager position are even not considered as people but as resources for utilization with no rights at all. If you contact with HR to discuss ethical violations, mobbing etc. from people being high in hierarchy, they only look at you with scared face, and they will do nothing because they afraid them. As you could imagine, there is no fun at all to work with them, which is reflected in a huge fluctuation rate... This is only a very top of an iceberg of problems there. Just only to name a few: low salaries, long working hours, lack of investment in people, office resembles a factory rather than creative workspace, widespread contempt etc. If you want to truly develop yourself professionally and personally you have to AVOID THIS PLACE AT ALL COST!

cons: Not the best place if you’re an engineer. Several ERP implementation roles are advertised as engineering roles but you’re not doing any engineering over there. The consulting  world is a flashy world for business people. Your technical skills as an engineer will not be appreciated.

headline: Senior Analyst
pros: Diverse, mostly great people to work with. If youre lucky, you have a good RL, unless youre at the specialist level. Spoiler alert: the rest are all cons.
cons:
Lack of opportunity in desired projects. Horrendous salary - I can resell 1 shoe a month and make more than this. Absolutely NO structure on promotion, despite putting in 100× more effort than your colleagues. Just favoritism and politics. 
They claim encouraging career progression but they will find ways NOT to promote you than the other way around. RL would rather push down on you with their ego than actually help. This office is an absolute joke and is treated like it is NOT part of PwC, but rather a separate entity (Acceleration Center) and there is not respect for its employees outside of it. Zero respect for people at my level as this is the only office that has a LOWER level than an Associate, which is a beginning level at any other office. We are treated like we are interns and have to literally lick ears to get promoted, which WILL NOT happen unless you're a White Male, at the specialist level. ENJOY. Whatever you do, DO NOT join at this level. It's Horrible.

headline: Great benefits, wonderful people throughout

cons:
- Limited room for diversification - you are likely to be placed on the same job for back to back for years because you have experience in it and it's obviously easier to have experienced people on the job rather than new. Good if you're interested in the company you're staffed on but not so great if you're not 
- Probably easier to get a job in a different line of service at a different big 4 / company than to try to move internally from one line of service to another
- Strong culture of working over time. But this is probably not news to anyone.

headline: Agonizing
pros: Big company, lots of different opportunities, tech management seems pretty open to people moving around on a regular basis
cons: Very business-driven, little to no regard for work life balance even though upper management preaches that it needs to be better.  Even if you land on a team with a good tech stack, most teams don't have any unit tests or automation but are expected to maintain flawless production performance. Developers consistently work late nights and weekends to get stories done.  No effort by tech leads to understand their associates' career interests and goals, all about the bottom line.  Poor utilization of developers existing skillsets.

headline: A2 option
pros: If you develop a partner relation they'll look out for you and advocate for you. Focus on diversity (excluding neurodiversity) and prioritizing I&D conversation on teams. Support from in pursuing ideas you think can be beneficial.
cons: The HR team isn't great and unless you have someone from a manager or partner-level advocating for your interest you have little control over your own career. As a new hire, you have little choice of what you work on. The firm messaging can be very contradictory to their actions. Personally, I have dyslexia (still a high performer) but when I reached out to HR for resources (proofreading software, connecting to a diverse group, and changing my coach) they were very toned def and I was the first person in my market to do so. After creating partner relationships, advocating, and openly discussing this disability the firm is slowing starting to handle this better. The hours are also insane and very understaffed. Health insurance is not great.
